One of my favourite Total Wars mainly because i love the roman era, never got bored and i still need to play the rest of the campaigns so far i only completed the Grand Campaign, Wrath of Sparta Rise of the Republic and Hannibal at the Gates.
There are a lot of playable factions which makes your game style change example, greeks maybe more defensive because of the spear infantry variety and barbarians more aggressive because of the melee infantry variety.
I consider this game to have one of the best land battles in the series and the management of your politics, civic infrastructures, armies and navy make it so you have to find a balance in all of them otherwise you will have some quite serious problems (at end game i got a secession and it completely demotivated me so i restarted a campaign).
Another thing that makes this game great are the mods on the workshop there are so many great mods that make the game 10x better (sometimes harder) and different like Divide et Impera.
Highly recommend you to play this game be it singleplayer be it multiplayer with co-op campaigns or straight up battles

Hard to the fault game in the overall perspective. The Ai in the campaign mode is relatively easy to manipulate after finding their patterns, especially in siege battles. although the hardest difficulty does provide decent challenges throughout. Multiplayer is mediocre, mostly when the battles nature is generally quite forced with limited scenarios. But to put it simply, by far the best ancient warfare sim to date.

I was suspending my disbelief as long as humanly possible. A dying country with 1 city somehow raising an army bigger than my own in 2 turns? Fine, it's @#%@ game design but I guess it's possible. Said empire repeatedly refusing excellent peace deals? OK. But THEN... The slave uprising happened. And SOME @#$%ING WAY, THE SLAVES HAD CAVALRY AND UNITS BETTER THAN WHAT MY ENEMY, AN *ACTUAL F#$@ING COUNTRY*, HAVE. What slave uprising have YOU heard of where the slaves had well armored cavalry and competently trained fighting units? 
Buy if you want to have enemies that somehow pull hordes of troops from their behind and random, bum-hick slave uprisings with better equipment than your entire army can afford.

Edit: Divide et Impera makes the game much more tolerable. My troops actually handle like you'd expect a roman legion to. That is to say, they don't crumble under some low-tier assault by the CRINGE Carthaginians and barbarians. Now, to be clear, the mod does make your starting position much uglier, but after you figure out how to beat that, it's fun all the way through. Still wouldn't recommend it at full price, though. Snag it on sale like I did.

[h1]The Bread and Butter of the Total War Series[/h1] [i]If you were just getting into the Total War series I would advocate starting here[/i] (if you don't mind an older game try Medieval II, stellar for it's time and still a very solid game). 

This game requires you to think and plan ahead, and it takes a lot of [strike]mistakes[/strike] trial and error. Each game is different, even if you play as the same faction; [b]adaptable AI[/b], which allows for some fun variety in each game. On top of that, there are [b]multiple ways to win[/b] in each playthrough, upon completion of required criteria, whether it be conquest, economic, or cultural victory. [i]I have played this game alone almost 500 hours and I am still far from feeling done with it.[/i] There are a few solid DLCs that add content to the base game that allow for new playable factions, which is rewarding for someone who wants to rise to power as a lesser faction.

P.S. The Total War series has unfortunately, not produced a game as solid as Rome II (timestamp: 2/20/2024).

[i]PROs[/i]
- Replayability
- Artistic unit cards
- Great unit detail
- City/Province management and building chains allow complete control of development, or lack thereof if you wish to have it auto maintained

[i]CONs[/i] 
- Difficulty setting when on Very Hard: AI decision-making is sometimes illogical just for the sake of boosting difficulty [i](such as random wars with factions you cannot see)[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[hr][/hr]

I appreciate anyone who has taken the time to read through my reviews. Ultimately, I hope these are helpful in the decision-making process. If you do purchase and/or have played the game and are seeing what others are saying, please feel free to give me feedback on your experiences.

Thanks and Happy Gaming!

I like it.
War, politics, historical realism, cultural expansion, technological upgrades, battles, spies, dignitaries, champions, trade, confederations, marriage, plagues, traits, traitors, astonishingly high infant mortality rates... what's not to like?
Just don't bother with the boats stuff because it's boring and unnecessary.
There are tons of diverse factions, although you do have to buy some in DLC.
There isn't any silly magical generals that completely undermine the historical strategy. The generals in this game have a realistic impact on nearby troops.
The grand campaign is fun for painting the map a single colour.
The Imperator Augustus DLC is fun for trying to hold together a fragile empire. In fact, it's better at this than the Attila TW title because at no point does the game magically start spawning in hordes that completely undermine the strategy you have been working on for the past 40 turns.
This game is also great for multiplayer, but I would recommend agreeing to some ground rules, such as:
Only 2 armies per region per turn.
No boat battles with the AI (unless you are willing to sit through hour-long battles where the AI sails back and forth out of range).
No besieging a settlement immediately after withdrawing from a battle in the same settlement in the same turn.

I mean if you like total war this is the prettiest one without the fantasy jargon.  

Still has all the frustrating bugs they've had for years, but there's no competition. AI gets to cheat, random reinforcement directions, units standing still (cav is the worst, cant have more than 2 units attack 1, followed by missiles only skirmishing with targeted units ignoring others advancing,) and ships cant land unless you go one by one leaving units stuck at sea forcing you to concede or wait 60 min for timer to run out... Oh and forget about naval battles bigger than 4v4. Just auto-resolve. (They hit it out of the park with empire and napoleon, don't know how they regressed so far.)  The list goes on. Majority could be bearable with a restart battle button but no, you must lose or exit to desktop. Why allow quick-save but not restart battle when the campaign map is the best functioning part of the game? If you're a total war fan you understand exactly what I'm talking about. Don't expect more.

That being said nothing else comes close, because there is nothing else. I love it for what it is though. Can be very fun in moderation, mods help a ton. Cant play too long before I have to go back to napoleon or empire. 

Under no circumstance should you pay $60 for it. Its like $15 from resellers. Good job CA for steering away prospective players with a full price tag on a 10 year old game.

The game just crashes to desk top. Settings are on low now.. And yes i have a really powerful PC, &  monitor &  memory and great Graphics card + memory.

The major problem of Rome 2 singleplayer (and multiplayer) is something that not even modders can fix sadly.


1. Only the capital city of province has city walls, while i am unable to just recruit soldiers to garrisons as i want. This is a terrible design as you cant defend properly your sate, and the stupid AI will annoy you a lot. On top of this there is limited building slot and resources are specific, making this "no wall" design way too much hassle. Also takes away the sandbox feel from the game. 

2. Armies are now bound to generals, which could be a good design and historical let say, but not when you cant build walls. Not when i am forced to micromanage a stupid family tree so i can have some generals, while the game doesnt even allow basic/meaningful diplomatic options. Armies should be limited and recruited from the population, with food supply, if anything. The way generals are implemented, are only fantasy/powercreep element in this game, all of this which hinders strategy and tactic.

These two things cant be fixed as i know with mods, and this is why i hate playing campaign, and in my opinion the AI cant handle these rules well.


3. Every sword unit has a pila. This not only made the game unbalanced and generic, but goes against history. The terrible implementation of phalanx also killed the greek factions.
Shogun 2 or even rome 1 had a good pikewall concept, sadly they didnt improved that direction. The way this game works, they should have called it Rome civil war.

4. Morale. The fourth and the last sin made by CA. It is way too high in this game, should be half the value as what it is now on every unit. With lower morale rome 2 could be more realistic and fun.

5. Time period and DLC. CA failed with the time periods and unit rosters as they cramped and mixed things into same place in the grand campaign, which hurts the multiplayer balance. Not only that, but they managed to release 2 dlc which period is already featured in the grand campaign. The development of this game is total chaos.

I want to enjoy this game, however the AI design ruins it. There's a cap of 2 armies when you, the player, are small. AI completely ignores this and will have 4 stacks coming out of a single village. 

AI ignores food, I can have spies draining their settlements and leaving them in negatives. They still take no attrition.

AI ignores upkeep. Tiny settlements will eventually "support" multiple elite stacks. While you, the player, will be barely struggling to maintain one stack. 

AI cheats. The developers designed it to do this. It's not even hard to see, and turns the game into a grind. 
This is because core issues from the sloppy & rushed release were never fixed.

Some mods fix these issues by adding more complexity. Overhauls like Radious & DEI do nothing to fix these issues. The former makes armies basically free, the latter makes the game "realistic" by being so hard it's not fun.

Developers chose to weave this AI cheating through all subsequent Warhammer titles. Great job CA!
The DEI Mod has made this game unbelievably good. Very addicting! They should have made the game like this originally.

[h1]“Epic Battles, Shaky Empires”[/h1]

[h2]Intro: Conquering the Ancient World, One Bug at a Time[/h2]

Rome II: Total War is like playing a game of chess, but with more fire, screaming, and the occasional glitch where your knight turns into a red and blue patchwork square marked "Texture." It's an ambitious attempt at bringing the grandeur of Ancient Europe to your screen, with mixed results.

[h2]“Massive Battles: When Size Does Matter”[/h2]

The game's battles are the stuff of legends – vast, cinematic, and incredibly detailed. It's like directing your own version of "Gladiator," except Russell Crowe occasionally walks through walls. These battles are as much about morale and tactics as they are about sheer force, giving you that authentic general-at-war feeling.

[h2]“The World is Your Playground...Sort of”[/h2]

The campaign map is a gorgeous, living, breathing entity, teeming with life, sound, and animation. It’s like a game of Risk but with better graphics and more backstabbing. However, don't get too lost in admiration, as you might find a bug or two lurking in the empire's underbelly.

[h2]“A Mixed Bag of Strategy”[/h2]

Total War: Rome II is a strategy powerhouse with an improved engine that unfortunately shows its age compared to newer titles. The game attempts to blend old and new mechanics, making it easier for newcomers to grasp the basics while retaining enough depth for veterans. Imagine trying to teach your grandpa to use a smartphone, but the smartphone is an entire ancient civilization.

[h2]“Sieges and Bugs: A Tale of Two Cities”[/h2]

City sieges are a highlight, wonderfully impressive and tactically engaging. However, be prepared for pathfinding issues where your soldiers might get as lost as a tourist in Rome. And the AI? Let's just say it's about as sharp as a marble statue.

[h2]Verdict[/h2]

[b]Graphics: 8/10[/b]
Like a beautiful fresco that occasionally loses a few tiles.

[b]Sound: 7.5/10[/b]
The clashing of swords and the cries of battle are music to any general's ears, but sometimes it hits a sour note.

[b]Gameplay: 7.5/10[/b]
A blend of strategy and action that's like a well-oiled chariot, except when a wheel falls off.

[b]Story: 6.5/10[/b]
An empire-building saga with enough intrigue to keep you hooked, but sometimes it feels like the scribe fell asleep.

[b]Overall: 7.4/10[/b]

[h2]Closing Thoughts: “A Trip Through Ancient Europe, Bugs Included”[/h2]

Total War: Rome II is like a grand tour of ancient Europe where you're both the tour guide and the conqueror. It's a thrilling journey through history with spectacular battles and strategic depth, but be prepared for the occasional pothole on your road to glory. And remember, even the mightiest empires had their flaws – Rome wasn't built in a day, and apparently, neither was Rome II: Total War without a few glitches.

I was not around for the original launch of this game.  I heard about the negative reviews regarding bugs and optimization, but I can't speak to how the game used to be.  I can say that Rome 2, in its current state, is a very good Total War (TW) game and worth buying (especially if on a Steam sale).  Is it the best game in the TW franchise? That is up for debate.  But I believe that a lot of the negativity associated with this game is unwarranted.

The positives:
A well-polished and optimized gameplay experience.  Compared to games like Empire and Attila, which have very ardent fanbases, this game runs extremely well, even at higher graphics settings.  I’ve found that even with bulky mods (DEI) the game holds up well.  The extensive post-launch updates to this game really show here.

Amazing breadth of factions and gameplay scenarios.  With all DLC’s enabled, the player has access to nearly 2 dozen factions, each with unique unit rosters, and several campaigns that create very immersive scenarios: Ceasar in Gaul; Empire Divided; Hannibal at the Gates; Rise of the Republic; Imperator Augustus; Wrath of Sparta.  Each campaign offers an unique experience worth the purchase; I frankly find them more engaging than the main campaign from a role-playing perspective.

Interesting new dynamics on the strategic map.  A full political system where family members and rival clans must be managed.  A food system to enable strategic buildings and avoid famine.  Sanitation and banditry systems (exclusive to the Empire Divided campaign) which impact public order and empire income.  The ability for certain factions to confederate into larger factions.  Governance penalties and civil wars for larger empires.  A general trait and army system that allows players to specialize and focus armies.  Supposedly, much of this content was not well implemented at launch, but a lot of naysayers don’t quite appreciate how much effort went into refining this content via DLC’s and updates.  

Beautiful strategic map with a variety of filters and layers to review different sorts of region information: faction ownership; economic potential; trade resources; political allegiance; diplomatic status; ect.  This strategic map, as well as the UI windows really do a good job of displaying a wealth of information to the player.  The fact that most TW games post Rome 2 (Atilla, Warhammer) continued to use and build upon that strategic layer says a lot.

Tactical gameplay.  A lot of people hate on the AI and the battle experience for Rome 2, but IMHO the game works well enough in this regard.  Is the battle AI going to truly challenge you (without the massive buffs applied at higher difficulty)?  No, and that has been the case for most titles pre and post Rome 2.  On the land and sea battles, the AI will act in a mostly logical fashion, with only the occasional jankiness.  Pathfinding and unit collision functions well for the most part, despite the underlying shortcomings with the Warscape engine.  I’ve seen a lot of complaints about how certain infantry (Phalanx units, Roman infantry) are too strong and cavalry lack punch, but this makes some sense due to how warfare of that age was primarily infantry based.

The negatives:
The removal of a true population system which impacted recruitment and city growth/wealth. 
 
Cities are now broken down into major (walled) and minor (unwalled) settlements, each with limited build slots.  There is less freedom on how to grow and develop each city, and certain historically important cities are relegated being minor unwalled settlements.  The provincial edict system associated with this new aspect, while interesting, doesn’t make up for degradation of player choice. Sadly, this concept has been carried forward into the future TW games.

All armies must be staffed/led by a general, again limiting player choice and flexibility.

Removal of trade routes between individual cities (continuing a trend that was started with Empire and Shogun).

No in-game building browser or encyclopedia.  Instead the game gives you a link to Creative Assembly website which contains next to no useful information.  A stupid oversight, and one that CA could have easily corrected post-launch, but never did.

Diplomacy and overall empire management can be a bit underwhelming at times.  While the AI will respond in a mostly logical fashion to diplomatic outreach and war actions, there can be unpredictable behaviors at times.  Similarly, it’s hard to understand the payoff or risks with the political intrigue and family interactions.  TW games have historically underperformed at the strategic and political layers, though newer titles (3 Kingdoms) have supposedly seen improvements in that area.  The dev’s definitely could have spent more time fleshing out this content.

Bottom-line: None of the above negatives are game-breaking, but it would have been nice for CA to have fully followed through on their implementation.  The game still is a very fun and immersive experience, more so with the right mods (of which there are many to choose from).  I see a lot of people complaining about how bland Rome 2 is compared to Attila – my take is that there is very little which separates the two in terms of core gameplay and mechanics.  After all, much of the content that earned Attila praise is ultimately traced back to Rome 2.  The key difference between the two games is that Attila offers a pre-fabricated doomsday scenario (Huns, political dissent, famine, climate change) which challenges the player with staving off defeat from turn 1.  Rome 2’s DLC’s offer different variations of a pre-staged scenario, but the main campaign has no such construct and is basically an open canvas for the player to paint upon as desired.  There is nothing wrong with either approach, and certain mods (DEI in particular) can make the classic empire-building a very challenging and replayable gameplay loop.

My recommendation to anyone starting this game: play Rome 2 vanilla DLC’s; and then experiment with the main campaign.  If you get to the point where you no longer find the gameplay challenging, try your hand at one of the mods (DEI, Parabellum).  I believe that there are many hundreds, if not thousands, of hours of enjoyment to be had if you explore all this game has to offer.

This is a very good game. The Total War series is the greatest battlefield simulator to ever exist. If you like a game where you control big armies armies and maneuver precisely where you want them on the battlefield you will love this game. It's all I ever wanted from a war game.

The Rome single player campaign is very good and will give you 40+ hours of enjoyment, more or less depending on your speed.

The controls on the battlefield are nice and causes me no problems. The only thing that sometimes get in my way is the mouse turning the camera right or left when I'm moving it across the screen. But I've learned to keep that to a minimal.

The amount of formations you can put your army in is amazing!

The simulator on the battlefield itself is gold! No other game series comes comes to simulating so many troops on the battlefield. Seeing your army fight up close with other armies is the best thing about this game.

I like battlefields and city battlefields that are simulated, especially the cities, they don't look like they are randomly generated.

The city building aspect on the campaign map is good and costs are reasonable. I actually like city building in this war game.

One thing that confuses me is the political system in the game. I Can't figure out how to get more senators for my house, and how to decrease senators from other houses. You can only spend so many hours on google, before you start going with the flow. Also, for some reason, the costs of political actions for new characters rises astronomically, the reason for this was never explained.

Lastly, I don't like about this game is the AI agents in the campaign map. The AI agent spam actions against you are all critical successes, they never fail. Your agents on the other hand will have 17%, 35%, 7% chances to succeed. These agents also cause the map to be cluttered. And at the end of your turn each AI will have to move around a half dozen of agents plus their armies, making the turns last longer.

- I crushed the rebellion putting an end to the civil war in my faction.
- The Etruscan league is fighting the Romans for control of the Tyrhenian Sea, but the Romans keep winning naval battles. 
- I settle a peace deal with the Numidians
- A slave uprising reaks havoc in my north Africa settlements

This is a tough one.
(All of this is my opinion so don't be mad if what I hate is what you like. Go write your own review)

Short summary: Yes, you should buy this game if you want to play campaign. Add on some mods and there is hundred's of hours of content. BUT... As a new player, if you want to play multiplayer, don't buy it. (read below)

Long review:
There are a few things which might change this above answer for you.
- In 2023 CA removed the ability to chat with other players. This makes multiplayer a horrible experience to jump into for new players. Not being able to ask questions and not knowing any of the common rules, such as 1 arty, 2 pikes, 4 ranged (124).
- You will also need to buy DLC factions to get the full multiplayer experience which makes it hard for me to recommend it to new players.
Campaign:
- While the base game is fun I would say modding is essential to get the full experience of the game. In my opinion you should play your first campaign as vanilla plus with a few QoL mods. Then play one of the overhaul mods, my favourite being Divide et Impera.
- The vanilla gameplay is very fun especially in field battles. Lines of infantry, ranged skirmishing and cavalry flanking.
- Sieges are also fun, however the AI is frankly just stupid. I love multiplayer sieges (which contribute to about 2/3 of my hours) but as above, it will be tough for new players to jump in.
- The campaign map is amazing and massive with many factions but... You will need to pay for extra factions (and thus extra campaigns).
A few negatives:
- The political/family system is confusing and tedious imo. 
- The population system was removed
- Armies can only travel with generals (no more small single unit armies)
- The province system divides provinces into a capital city with walls and smaller towns which can NEVER build walls. This contributes to a much worse experience than Rome 1 imo.

Ok, I'll wrap it up. 
Campaign. Yes buy it. Add on some mods and enjoy.
Multiplayer. Don't buy it unless you are willing to join a community such as a discord which will help you out.

After nearly ten years, I can say that this game holds up well to time. I bought the game on release and it is has been a long road to what the game is now, but the developers and modders made this game a top ten strategy game of all time. The top down map is easy to traverse and the UI is a lot more intuitive than most modern games. The actual in-game real time battles are addicting, watching your horses or elephants trample the enemy, or your pikes take the piss out of some cavalry.
  With mods such as Divide Et Impera, the game really shines. If it was released right now in 2024, it would hold up really well and perhaps Total War would be doing better haha.. They should return to the classics, like this gem.

Swear to god, this game is just crash central. It's taken three install-uninstall's to even get this game to let me into the campaign map and even then it almost crashes every 5 - 10 minutes on the map or in a battle. Just ridiculously bad along with little support on addressing the issues. 

The actual game is ok when I get to play it. Interesting changes to the campaign's settlement management system. Squalor is no longer crippling but this is about the only positive change here. The rest of the changes to the UI and district systems seem superfluous and have little substance behind them providing no additional challenges or strategic management incentives to get excited about. 

In battles it took a little getting used to the new UI and finding out how to arrange loose formations or place siege/defensive equipment wasn't obvious at first but nothing a google didn't solve. Interesting tweaks to powers of units and hoplites seem to have been given a nerf until you figure out how to use them properly in the new combat systems. Any spear unit seems to just stand there doing not much even when engaged until you spam attack on the opponent to cause them to keep moving forwards - little frustrating. But all in all a solid attempt at a TW game. Not my fave, but not terrible. Worth a purchase when on sale if you like grand strategy games. 6.5/10 when it works.

The turn-based strategy is a fun campaign, especially multiplayer. Plenty of nuance to getting that straight, and I still haven't figured out a lot of it. Empire and family management is more confusing than, say, learning Civilization VI, and also simpler. The turn-based strategy and battles fought in real time are an awesome mixture. Civilization VI doesn't have real-time tactics, and Age of Empires is overwhelming because it has no turns and everything is a race. This is the perfect balance to get the best of both worlds. You get very invested in your nation throughout the campaign, and the story written along the way is neat. I find playing just single battles from the main menu boring, but when playing a campaign and knowing how each battle fits into your larger strategy, that this battle is to capture a settlement and grow your empire, or upon this battle hinges the fate of one of your settlements, or you are desperately trying to turn back the enemy army before they reach your settlement — those give each battle a unique meaning and importance.

The battles are slow enough to keep your head wrapped around everything (and you can speed them up when you feel sure of yourself), and they feel very realistic, to an extent (other than some wacky fantastical units). Formations are important, and battles are won by maneuver and turning flanks; frontal attrition is a slaughter. It's not very intuitive to learn the nuances of the game (like what units beat which other units, though the basics of sword/spear/cavalry make sense), but I like the fact that applying real-life tactics will win you battles. There are many different ways one could arrange a force and go about pursuing the battle, and you always have to be watching and reacting to your opponent's movements. You can't just have a mob as in Age of Empires; maintaining order and control of your formations and keeping your units together is the difference between victory and rout. I can even see the tactical principles in Clausewitz's On War showing in many battles, which I think is a sign of a good simulation. If I can read military literature like Clausewitz and apply it to win battles in Rome: Total War, that is the pinnacle of a realistic simulation where I can play general in a historical universe, even if the units themselves aren't 100% historically accurate. That is what I was hoping to get when I bought this game, and it has not disappointed me.

I have found one bug that lost me a battle because the AI wouldn't land a boat of missile infantry, and I couldn't destroy the ship with my missile infantry on shore (ran out of ammunition, and couldn't set it on fire before that happened), forcing me to concede defeat. I'll autoresolve next time. No big deal, albeit annoying.

TL;DR: Would I recommend it? Absolutely. If you’re looking for a good strategy game, a good historical game, or a good historical strategy game, you won’t go wrong with it.

NTL;DR: At this point I have played every single faction in every single campaign at least once. That does not mean I [i]actually know[/i] what I’m talking about, but I’m going to be [i]really good[/i] at pretending I do.
Word to newcomers to the Total War series: This was actually my first TW game. The initial learning curve is going to feel steep, but it won’t take very long until you get used to it. The training campaign is a little wonky but learning via Multiplayer is, from experience, a viable option if you have a friend/contact so inclined.
Without further ado:

[h3]THE BAD:[/h3]

• Diplomacy is on the clunky side. For example, you cannot tell your own satrapies/client states to stop warring against each other or [i]by all your gods as well as mine I will turn this Trireme around and we’re going to row back all the way home [b]you absolute ingrates[/b][/i].
Your ability to turn soon-to-be-enemy alliances on each other or at least break up large defensive alliances with Machiavelli-style machinations is also very limited, as the AI will almost never cooperate with anything you do. Even allies. [i]Especially[/i] allies. There are ways, but they are very mechanical and non-intuitive.

• There is a persistent null-pointer exception error causing a crash to desktop in the game, both single- and multiplayer. That one is reproducibly caused by tearing down too many walls on siege maps and/or having too many “objects” (read: corpses) piling up in the same small area. Sadly, this means you cannot use Ballistae or Chariots and Elephants as much as you would like to without running that risk. I have had entire campaigns without any crashes at all by minding this though, so otherwise stability is quite good.

[h3]THE MEH:[/h3]

• If you are looking for an in-depth economy or cultural simulator, this ain’t it. You do have to take care that you don’t annoy people too much (who’d have thought people hate having food surplus so much? Rhetorical question, just to be obvious). Other games do that better, but if you are looking for a surface-level mash-up of simulation and tactics, you’ll do fine.

• Not something I blame the game or its creators for, but informative nonetheless: The historical information is partially outdated at this point. Mind, it is still quite detailed and can serve as a kickstarter to the interested, but the game is quite old at this point and science marches on.

• Generally, the AI is not very sophisticated. Again partially absolved by the age of the game, but if you’re looking for a hardcore challenge, even the highest difficulty level does not make the AI smarter. It’s all numerical boosts/nerfs. Consult your friendly neighborhood modding community for fixes. Civil war tension can be interesting, but after the tenth in the same campaign that you crushed in one turn, you start to wonder why people still voluntarily attack you.

[h3]THE GOOD:[/h3]

• The game is giving you all the information you need. Reading stat cards is straightforward and you can quickly compare even between your units and enemy ones (not on higher difficulties). Balance is likewise sensible: If it’s more expensive, barring [i]very[/i] few gimmick units, it’ll perform accordingly.

• Replay value is really pretty good. Each culture group handles more or less same-ish (with the Thracians as a notable exception), but between the cultures you can – and sometimes must have – considerable variation. Playing Iberians as if they were Greeks will make you have a bad time, while playing Steppe tribes as if they were Romans makes Baby Jesus cry and you a sad panda. You [i]can[/i], if you like, go the standard 8/6/3/3 mêlée/ranged/artillery/cavalry with [i]most[/i] cultures and get away with it just fine, but by no means do you need to. Also, in each campaign you may be confronted with different cultures on account of RNG, meaning even with the same faction you may end up having to fight battles differently from before.

• Historical information is, as mentioned, not bleeding-edge, but you’ll still learn quite a few things that can broaden your horizons. If nothing else, you’ll be better at geography than you were before. Some of the sayings mentioned are also [i]disturbingly[/i] applicable in and to modern life.

Conclusion: Even after playing this much, there’s still fun in it. Multiplayer makes for much better coordination too, opening up some new playstyles that are not feasible in single-player. I would have more points for each list (but mostly the ‘good’ or ‘meh’ ones), and I haven’t even gotten into the DLC campaigns, but this review is already bloated beyond reason or sanity.
 
END OF TEXT WALL, and thank you for reading. Hope it helped!

I wouldn't buy this game again. Even on sale.

Its tolerable, but barely.  6.5/10 for enjoyment.  Its still a total war game though, even if the game isn't as fun as before.  It looks good too, but definitely not great.  They fixed the massive list of game ruining issues and bugs finally so thats a thing, however it still has several major design flaws that got passed on to every game after.  Namely the province system (which i despise), the army system (mostly a detriment), the political system (which amounts to paying to keep your empire from revolting and thats it), and the still absolutely atrocious diplomacy system.  Word of advice, if you have vassals of any kind, kill them, they are dead weight, and the vassal and satrapy system are completely empty and devoid of any benefit to you.  They also took out population and now your cities can't be upgraded however you want, they have a set number of tiles to build on and then your done and most of them are locked into being small settlements without walls.  You also can't move your capitol anymore.  Combat boils down to stats now not tactics, so forget terrain, momentum, morale, exhaustion, and formations too a lot of the time. They don't matter, only stats do, so match up your units versus what they are good against and bash them against the enemy or whittle them down with tons of ranged units, anything else is usually a mistake.  Mod the game, it makes it better.  A couple mods like Divide et Impera make it an 8/10.

Italy's north has warm summers and cool winters. Italy's south has hot summers and mild winters.

If you think about the Roman Empire often, this may be the game for you. Not as good as Shogun 2 or 3 Kingdoms, but better than plenty of others. Total War: Rome II stands as a triumphant testament to grand strategy gaming. The meticulously crafted world of ancient warfare comes to life with stunning visuals and attention to historical detail. Playing as the mighty Rome or the intricate Seleucid Empire offers distinct and immersive experiences, each with its unique challenges and strategic depth.

The campaign, set against the backdrop of the classical era, provides an epic canvas for conquest and diplomacy. The depth of faction-specific mechanics ensures that each playthrough feels fresh and engaging, whether you're expanding the Roman Republic or navigating the complexities of the Seleucid Empire.

The attention to historical accuracy is commendable, from the diverse unit rosters to the sprawling cities that evolve through the ages. The battles, whether epic clashes or tactical sieges, capture the essence of ancient warfare with breathtaking animations and realistic combat mechanics.

Total War: Rome II excels not only in strategic depth but also in the sheer scale of its battles. The variety of units, coupled with the strategic intricacies, offers an immersive experience that keeps you captivated for hours. The extensive modding community adds even more longevity, allowing players to tailor their experience to suit personal preferences.

Whether you're a fan of Rome's imperial might or the intricate diplomacy of the Seleucid Empire, Total War: Rome II delivers a grand strategy experience that remains unparalleled. It's a must-play for enthusiasts of historical strategy games, offering a captivating journey through the annals of ancient history.

When I initially reviewed this game, my verdict was a resounding "NO." However, the Emperor Edition has genuinely turned things around for the better. Nevertheless, my reservations persist, especially regarding the steep cost of DLC compared to the base game. While the modding community has produced some commendable content, there's room for improvement in the available options.

Certain changes, like the reduction in garrison strength, leave me puzzled, and I yearn for Rome to have a more meaningful connection with the Senate. The ability to customize Rome's color to match the chosen house would have been a welcome addition. On a positive note, the revamped politics system is a highlight.

In my Roman co-op experience, the AI proved its mettle in strategic maneuvering, forming confederations and forcing us into a challenging war for control over Gaul and parts of Germania. It's disheartening to see complaints about the AI's inadequacy in the Rome 2 community—my advice: try playing on a higher difficulty.

I appreciate the AI's focus on capturing key points and forcing tactical retreats in city streets. The improvement in AI behavior, like refraining from running cavalry into pikes, adds to the immersion. Diplomacy, however, could use some refinement; my attempt to offer 5000 for a trade was inexplicably rejected.

Navy battles have become more engaging, with land armies unable to overpower navies. The enhancement of archers is a positive step, though a broader distribution across factions would have been preferable (thankfully, mods can address this).

Introducing a turn timer, allowing players to customize the passage of in-game years, is a suggestion worth considering. I also advocate for expanding build slots, as the current limitations in towns/cities leave something to be desired. A longing for features like spies attempting assassinations and pre-battle speeches by generals remains unfulfilled.

In essence, while improvements have been made, there's still untapped potential and room for refinement in various aspects of the game.

Update: And at the moment of posting this, I went to the store page and it went on sale for $15 (down from $60). FML.

TL;DR: Don't risk it. It's overwhelming complicated at first and then becomes a pretty lame formula fast. In the first ~50 hrs of game play, expect hours 35-45 to be novel as you get the hang of it as a newbie. Then it returns to just being plain bad minus the novelty of something new.

It's buggy, boring, overly complex and after 70hrs of playing I pretty much have it down to a formula. Naval battles involve artillery to bombard with small but quick ships to distract enemy ships while you pulverize them. 

The computer AI(which is a VERY generous way to describe it) has literally ONE tactic for land AND naval battles. Just a SINGLE way of attacking/defending and that is supposed to fill 100hrs+ of gameplay so....you be the judge.

I have memories of playing Medieval TW and I do recall it being rough around the edges but kinda fun. This game was a little fun for a while...but would I pay over $20 for it in 2023? Oh my god no, it's clear they were too busy making DLC for you to purchase rather than giving the computer SOME variety in how it fights.

The computer in campaign literally controls every faction. So don't be surprised if the moment one nation prepares to attack you, there is another preparing to do the same as if they are somehow being coordinated... How about that? Additionally the comp doesn't adhere to any rules you have to. Food, population happiness, etc are all just for show if you are the comp. The diplomacy and politics are such a joke it's painful to imagine why any of the engineers making could think they were nailing it. 

Pretty sh*t game tbh. It tries to be this huge, amazing historical strategy game with different aspects of empire building to consider but beyond that, it doesn't actually.... try. 

And I mean at any of it. They are too busy writing dumb descriptions about ancient Roman barracks and Celtic horseman to actually tell you what the building/units stats are. It is literally the old TW games with new graphics and that is about it, so please. It is 2023, I'm sure there is a fresh new RTS/empire building game out there that is worth you time. Total War, Civilization, these are all games riding off the accomplishments of more imaginative people.

For an experienced player this game is too easy. Main campaing turns into a chore instead of feeling like a game with meaningful decisions. Initially I really enjoyed the game but find myself getting bored as time has gone on. Played many different factions on legendary and various difficulties. Though a fun game at times, it will leave you wanting more as you play beyond a few campaings. Any pike faction is brutally easy, even the horse archer tribes are easy once mastered. 

I do like this game but for the price and the ai being unable to provide late - mid game challenges I would not recommend buying it unless it was on sale. Medieval 2, Shogun 2 have a higher replay value and decisions feel more impactfull. Honestly shogun 2 is a masterfull game that is hard even having played it many times. The political system is broken imo. Having to deal with factions trying to split within your empire gets tedious. The game in general feels repetitive. Beyond turn 60-100 there is minimal challenge. I often know I am going to win and get stuck fighting 2v1 battles until the enemy has no one left to throw at me. Late game I can autoresolve almost every battle. With sparta for example, I declared war on everyone around me and won simply by holding choke points and watching the enemy rush my pikes. If they fixed the ai on a strategic level, made it so factions get bigger in main campaing to provide a better challenge and lowered the price. I would change my review.

Nah. Just play Attila instead.

- Economy makes no sense and is poorly explained. Why am I suddenly losing boatloads of money after conquering a third of the map when everything was fine before? Why do I lose lots of money every few turns? I don't get it and the game doesn't explain it.

- Building and unit icons are ugly. The interface omits relevant info (like the age of the people you can choose as generals). Attila does this way better.

- Victory conditions in campaign take too long to achieve and may even be completely unreasonable. Once again, Attila is superior.

- Battles are not fun and make no sense. Cavalry charges are so weak that it's borderline pointless to even try. How is it that when I'm charging multiple cavalry units into enemy infantry units that are pinned down and have their backs turned to me only 5 guys die and nobody routs, even on the lowest difficulty? The only good use for cavalry in this game seems to be fighting unprotected archers.
Also, heavy infantry is way overpowered and takes ages to kill no matter what you do. You're better off just auto-resolving that sh*t. Attila's battles aren't perfect either but at least cavalry charges feel appropriately powerful there (and can counter heavy infantry) and I don't get the overpowering urge to auto-resolve everything like in Rome II. 
Also, the city layouts suck - once again, Attila is a massive improvement because it actually gives some tangible advantages to the defenders.

- Faction politics are poorly explained and cumbersome to deal with. I'm a broken record at this point, but Attila does it better.

- Creative Assembly hates and belittles their customers. But I guess you have to deal with that if you wanna play Total War.

OVERALL: 4.5/10. Play Attila instead or Rome I if you want to stay in the same time period. Both are superior games.

"Total War: ROME II - Emperor Edition" is a monumental game in the strategy genre that transports players into the world of ancient warfare. Here is a comprehensive review with ratings in various categories:

**Overall Rating: 4.5/5 Stars**

1. **Graphics: 4.5/5 Stars**
   - Pro: The graphics in "Total War: ROME II" are impressive and detailed, with breathtaking landscapes and realistic battlefields.
   - Contra: On lower settings, the graphics can be less impressive, and there are occasional graphical glitches.

2. **Gameplay: 4.5/5 Stars**
   - Pro: The gameplay is deep and varied, with a combination of turn-based strategies and real-time battles. Warfare feels authentic and tactically demanding.
   - Contra: The game can initially be overwhelming, and the AI is sometimes unpredictable.

3. **Control: 4/5 Stars**
   - Pro: The control is well designed and allows players to effectively manage large armies.
   - Contra: The control can initially seem complex, especially for new players in the Total War franchise.

4. **Innovation: 4/5 Stars**
   - Pro: "Total War: ROME II" improves many aspects of its predecessors and introduces new elements such as enhanced political and diplomatic options.
   - Contra: Despite some innovations, the game remains true to many traditional Total War mechanics, which could be seen as a lack of radical innovation.

5. **Story and Atmosphere: 4.5/5 Stars**
   - Pro: The historical atmosphere is captivating, and the campaigns are designed with great attention to detail.
   - Contra: The story elements could be more strongly developed to delve deeper into historical events and figures.

**Additional Pros and Cons:**

- **Pro:**
  - Wide selection of factions and units suitable for different play styles.
  - Extensive multiplayer mode that enhances the gaming experience.

- **Contra:**
  - Occasional bugs and performance issues, especially in larger battles.
  - Some players report an imbalance in game balance that makes certain strategies overpowering.

Overall, "Total War: ROME II - Emperor Edition" offers an impressive and immersive gaming experience that will delight fans of historical strategy games. It combines complex strategy with detailed and realistic battles, making it one of the standout games in the Total War series.

Okay after going through the older games i gotta say, what the fuck is this. Even after buying on sale i still feel scammed. This new province system is a downgrade from shogun, the combat is surface level with no depth. The only thing that possibly saves this is DEI but mods can only take you so far.

I used to not believe the people who always bashed the newer games but honestly, they are correct, everything is down hill from here. 

On its own its a ok game, but compared to the older total war games it is nothing except a complete cash grab filled with DLC along with many of the good mechanics being removed from the older games.

If you love DEI and its combat, take a look to the past and try the older games in this series. this is a downgrade in every way imaginable, even the graphics (its only saving grace) looks dated.

Et tu Rome 2?

Well, I just wanted to redo this review, without deleting it and starting completely over.

I'm not going to lie. When I played Rome 2, I mostly played the multiplayer battles, which can still be fun if you play with a few friends. 

But my point is that I don't have tons of experience with the campaigns.

I will however say that I do think that this game, Total War: Rom 2, is a good game, despite what some CA haters may say.

Yeah, the game had a terrible launch, but CA put a LOT of effort into fixing it, and while they didn't make it absolutely perfect, I will say that they made the game far better than some other companies would've.

CA could've just written Rome 2 off and let it die, but they didn't. They stuck with it.

And because CA stuff with it, we got some majorly great mods that add so much to the game, which might not have happened if CA just given up on it.


So I will say, that while not perfect, Rome 2 is a pretty solid TW game and is worth buying.

(October 3, 2018 update):

I used to like playing this game, I really do. But when things change--sometimes for the worse--my thoughts on this game change as well.

[b][u]Everything Wrong With [i]Total War: Rome II[/i]:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] Vanilla gameplay is downright [b][i]terrible[/i][/b]. Steam Workshop mods make the game [b]WAY[/b] better, but have the chance of being ruined by each new official update/patch.
[*] Patch 20/[i]Rise of the Republic[/i] "Family Tree" system completely misses the point of why fans wanted it in the first place.  
[*] No "Man of The Hour" events.
[*] No way to acquire settlements through diplomatic deals.
[*] QOL: No way to type a [i]specific[/i] amount of money in the "Offer/Demand Payment" diplomacy option.
[*] QOL: No weapon, shield, and armor upgrades in Custom Battle.  
[*] QOL: Minor settlements don't have rudimentary wooden walls/defenses.
[*] QOL: Exchanging units between armies is tedious thanks to a poorly thought-out design for the army exchange windows instead of wider windows with more detailed view of the units being exchanged.
[*] [i]Power and Politics[/i] (introduced in Patch 18) was improved in Patch 19, but Patch 20 ditches it anyway and adds even more unnecessary complications.
[*] "Imperium Level" Army/Fleet cap is (artificially) restrictive, especially in a game where you can expect every faction from outside and within to betray you.
[*] QOL: Naval combat still needs polishing.
[*] QOL: "Duty Calls" event is as annoying as a pop-up ad.
[*] QOL: Unit pathfinding is still problematic at times. (They've had that problem since [i]Rome I[/i].)
[*] QOL: Units still have a "delayed reaction" to orders. (Another problem since [i]Rome I[/i].)
[*] Game devs do not provide the last stable version of each patch, forcing the player to either roll back to a "beta version" that causes problems with mods that used to work with the last stable patch--or go update to the newest patch which breaks the player's ongoing save games and Steam Workshop mods.
[*] DLC rarely goes below 50% discount during Steam Sales. When I asked why they aren't offering a lower discounted price for older DLCs during their promotion for [i]Total War: Three Kingdoms[/i], they never gave a straight, honest answer and deleted the comment.
[*] That limit to the amount of active game mods. Nice work spoiling players' fun, CA... /s (But i guess they have bigger problems to worry about now...)
[/list]

See also: http://www.twcenter.net/forums/showthread.php?628677-Everything-Rome-1-had-that-Rome-2-doesn-t

TL;DR: [b]Should you get this game?[/b] If you're just gonna play vanilla, then [b]eff NO[/b]. [i]Rome II[/i] is still far from improved in its base form. Go get [i]Total War: Warhammer[/i], [i]Shogun 2[/i], or even the original [i]Rome: Total War[/i] instead. Heck, even [i]Empire[/i] would be a better deal. The only way I can recommend [i]Rome II[/i] again is when it's at 75% off (including [b]ALL[/b] DLC), allow full support for game mods regardless of game version, and fix the aforementioned QOL issues above.

Then again, it's been a long-a** while since I heard any new updates besides DLC, and considering that newer [i]Total War[/i] games are CA's main focus now, [i]Rome II[/i] still remains a letdown.

When I originally played, I did the prologue mission and never turned the game on again. Its impressive they made a tutorial as abysmally bad as this one. It throws a ton of information at you without giving you much of any explanation, a lot of heavily skewed battles towards the AI, making it just a dumpster overall. 

Decided to give it another chance. Just went into a campaign blind this time, figuring things out and following the advisor.. was 10x smoother of an experience. For the average player I would just suggest a youtube video over the terrible tutorial this game has. Once you get the basics down, this game is a blast. There's enough depth to allow for hundreds, if not thousands of hours of gameplay between the crazy amount of different campaigns, and a high skill ceiling with the RTS battle mechanics. 

If you ever thought about giving this game a try, I'd highly recommend it, just be ready to be overwhelmed with mechanics for the first 5-10 hours.

I decided to play as Rome because Rome is based. I then conquered territories around me. After that I decided to expand westward and conquer Iberia. After I conquered Iberia, I decided to conquer Carthage. Carthage was so terrible that I autoresolved their whole empire. After autoresolving Carthage I decided provoking a political party would be funny. They seceded. The secessionist army met Legio II at the Battle of Numantia. Romans had to slay their brothers, it was a bloody day. The darkest turn in my whole campaign. The secessionists were defeated and Rome is at peace. But to win the game I had to conquer more. I decided to head eastward toward Asia Minor, conquering Greek cities along the way. I conquered all of Gaul to enter Britannia. Britannia was a drag. The Britons had 20 stack armies and navies. I had to use my big brain strategies to conquer Britain. But the problem is that whenever I defeated an army and conquered the city, another 20 stack would come and take the city with no resistance while my main army was away besieging another city, leading to a back and fourth war. But the war in Asia Minor was the absolute worst. It was just 20 stacks attacking my depleted army after I took a city, leading to many legions ceasing to exist. Whenever I did beat their 20 stack spam, another faction decides that they hate me and declares war on me, bringing their 20 stacks to conquer an undefended city. What's worse is that another secession happened. I autoresolved the secessionists since luckily they sucked, but Asia Minor was still a problem. I decided to raise another legion to conquer Sparta because they had territories in Asia Minor. They got defeated pretty easily, except for 2 battles that I had to manually fight. Luckily, a faction in Asia Minor loved that I declared war on Sparta, so I made a military alliance with them, since they had a lot of territory and it would count their territories to the victory thing. I then conquered Egypt since they declared war on me. I pushed back the 20 stack armies one by one, suddenly Asia Minor was looking to be a success. I then used my legions in Gaul to conquer Germanic tribes. At last, the final few cities fell and I had all I need. 90 pure cities. All required provinces. I had won. I had won the campaign. Never felt more accomplished in my life.

So long story short, this game is fun and enjoyable. The game to me is a 10/10. There are no flaws to it other than the Ai 20 stack army spam. The game has a lot to it, and I would definitely recommend it to people. Maybe someday when you buy this, you might have such a memorable and fun campaign as I had.

Old TW features:
Shogun 2 had a better system than this. You had the faction leader and his brothers in another group. You had a generals in a group. They all had family trees. You could assign any of them to do certain things like be a commissioner of war, finance etc. It was a pretty cool feature.

In Empire it showed you who ruled a region like the governor and other certain people like on the British parliament. 

Medieval 2 you could marry your princess into another faction or bring a general into you faction and make a alliance. 

If you had features like these it would increase the depth of running a empire by a ton! It is so boring now and nothing really. You can not marry generals on command or atleast have a event pop up for one before they die. 

Like who the hell is running my empire in Rome 2? I do not even know. lol

I've been playing Total War since I was in middle school when it came out in 2004 and I was 11 years old. Back then, my favorite past-time was just seeing how big of an army of peasants I could beat with 1 unit of roman elites. I spent countless hours messing around in battles, listening to heroic speeches (and cheating at the game because I was 11 and didn't quite get the campaign).

I was pumped beyond belief when I heard Rome II got announced and bought it immediately (in my Freshman year of college, boy how time flies) only to not be able to play it because of how broken it was on launch. But it got fixed and countless more hours were spent and finally some campaigns beaten.

In that time I've also played Shogun 2, Empire, Medieval 2, 3k, Thrones, Attila, Warhammer I & 2 & 3 (Check my steam library, they're all there). I even bought the Remastered version just because I love Total War.

And now, I will never, ever, ever do that again due to their ridiculous downfall. Stop releasing bad games and silencing dissent. Absolutely ridiculous this even needs to be said.

Rome II is a truly magnificent reimagining of the masterful never to be outclassed Rome: Total War. It started out roughly but was worked over adequately enough to be justifiably "good" after all the patches. I love how they included so many different cultures with inherent bonuses for each faction/race as well. Truly an epic and immersive "single" player campaign experience which for me is what Total War has always been about in the first place. It has so much replayability and every playthrough will turn out completely different. Hoping for a solid reboot of the online multiplayer Total War: Arena on the Steam platform. 9/10 amazing experience for the Total War beginner or experienced players who for whatever wild chance haven't played it yet.
Honestly I love this game! I know it had a lot of hate at release but what game doesn't? I Would highly recommend if you like turn based strategy games!

I cannot recommend any CA published game at this time due to the malicious way that the company and has treated its consumer base in recent years. CA has essentially banned criticism of them or their products within the steam forums for their games. They insist if one must be critical of the game that they provide a solution to fix the problem. This is nigh impossible for me as I am not a software developer or well-versed on how these games work under the hood. Therefore my advice on how to fix things must instead be focused on the need to engage constructively with the fan base, not alienate people who have spent hundreds of dollars on their games over the years, and been the base of the company's success over the last two decades. I also suggest that DLC prices moving forward be reduced to reflect the paucity of value they provide to the game. Additionally I would greatly appreciate new content to reflect what has been promised to consumers in the past (3k scrapped DLC). If anyone at CA or their parent company SEGA wants to discuss further suggestions I have I invite them to message me. I would be happy to have a constructive chat on why I have felt unwilling to purchase recent releases from what has historically been my favorite video game series.

Edit: After over 1000 hours and about 10 years, this game is ready with some caveats.

Rating: 8/10 vanilla, 10/10 with the right mods.

1. Mods. Get mods. If you want a simple Total War experience, get Para Bellum. If you want historical accuracy, intricacy, and you like some aspects of Paradox games, get DEI.
2. Rome 2: DEI is best Rome 2. It's tricky, it takes some getting used to, but it has the best depth and replay-ability of the mods/expansions. There are population mechanics, thousands of new units, and so many campaign actions feel satisfying. It's HARD to start playing, and that's ok. Use battle difficulty normal, campaign difficulty based on your Total War background. If you have 1000 hours on Total War games on Hard, start on normal. If you're newer, start on Easy. There are YT videos and guides for starting out economy-wise, and the Discord is very active. I like Immersaholic faction guides for picking a faction and some hints on starting out. Media Atropatene is my favorite because I like to rain enough arrows to blot out the sun, but if you're into Greek factions, there are dozens of Greek factions with hundreds of Greek units. And yes, Rome has more depth than ever too.
3. There's too much DLC, and it all costs money. Personally, I think the main game feels worth full price at this point. It's broad, and has plenty of content. As for DLC, wait for a sale and/or pick what's important to you. If you want blood, like me, get the Blood DLC and just role your eyes and glare in the general direction of the UK as you pay $3 for something that should be included in the base game.
4. Where is this compared to other Total War games? For games about Rome, I would start with the remake of Rome: TW. It's simple, and collision in battles is fun. For medieval games, I would go Medieval 2: TW if you're under 50 years old, Medieval 1: TW if you're over 50 and really don't care about graphics and have enough patience to run it, and then third is the 1100AD mod for Rome 2. I'd put Attila and 1212AD after 1100AD due to optimization issues with Attila.
5. My remaining problems with Rome 2. There are a few bugs that will never be fixed or modded out, like with the accumulation of political influence of the third political party, and the collisions in battle aren't as satisfying as with older games like Rome 1 and Medieval 2. If you want to dopamine hit from a big collision in Rome 2, use ramming in naval battles. Watching ships split in half with some solid audio is always fun for me.

OVERALL: 8/10 vanilla, 10/10 with DEI, and probably 3rd best historical TW after Rome 1 and Medieval 2.

I've played a lot of Rome total war and Rome remastered back then and loved it immensely, but when I decided to move onto Rome 2 and finally give it a shot around late 2022 , I was blown away. In my opinion , this is Rome remastered amplified by 10,000 and it was the historical experience I was looking for in a game especially in a total war based game, The campaign map looks glorious and the unit detail is amazing , the music is very good as well being utilized in many historical youtube channels Kings and Generals being one of them, the family tree system not being there at the start i heard , when finally implemented, gives for an immersive experience when handling your vast empire/kingdom/ republic/ principality etcetera. The battles....my god the battles. Another aspect of the game that gets utilized in some historical channel videos to simulate or replicate a battle that happened during those times, huge step from Rome 1 or Rome remastered... Lol, the only thing I disliked was the lack luster diplomacy system but even then it's 'alright' at best. Compared to Empire or medieval series. All in all , 8 out of 10 experience. I love it . and Have played way more Rome 2 then I did the past installment. There is so much content here it's not even funny. With DLC's and such. With mods as well your overall experience gets enhanced by a long shot. Really love This game and highly recommend it among my friends.

This was the biggest step back the Total War Series ever took, seriously the launch for this game as such an apocalyptic nightmare i waited TWO YEARS for it to be fixed and become playable. However credit where credit is due:

Battles are top notch and if you are into ancient rome or ancient greeks or ancient everything THIS IS THE GAME. Hundreds of units, hundreds of ancient civilizations, varied troop roosters, superb level of detail on the unit models. If this game was just battles and not campaign i'd be the most aethetically pleasing battle sim on earth. 

However the campaign is just utter crap. This is the game that killed the total war franchise forever. Design decisions taken during the development of ROME II still linger to this day in the series, and those are some awful design decisions. 

What made me play this for an insane amount of hours is the battles and their majestic detail. Cities are beautifull, units are gorgeous, playstyles are varied. And the DLC'S cover EVERY IMPORTANT CONFLICT OF THE TIMES, except for Alxeander the Great's campaign's, which is a shame. 

It's hard to give a score on a game that launched like shit, took two years to fix, has dumbed down the Total War series forever YET is gorgeous and super detailed. 

The veredic is decided by mods. There are a BAZILLION workshop mods that fix most of the trash in the game. 

So altho i dont play this anymore and find it boring now, the dlcs and mods make it worth your purchase. 

Should you get it? it comes down to one thing: Loving the Roman Empire. If you are one of those dudes, just get it.  Otherwise i still recommend it but be aware, this game is conflicting. Please refund if you dont like it, Creative assembly doesn't deserve the money for this one. It is the one ring that destroyed them all. 

This is the most painfull recommended i'll ever give in a review. After all i've been tru, rome 2 still deserves a buy, simply for being the best ancient battle simulator out there.

Attempting to navigate this game is akin to steer a chariot through a maddening modern-day traffic jam – an exquisite cocktail of confusion, chaos, and a hefty dose of lacking the faintest clue what is unfolding. I mean, there are these self-proclaimed swanky chaps wielding swords and shields, though I put good money on the fact that I accidentally engaged in a full-blown war with my very own city-state. Oh, the glory!

To give a grandiose salute to the elephants. Who in their right mind decided to throw these hulking behemoths into the fray? Were they aiming for a historical reenactment, or did someone just miss the memo on the location?

If you are the sort who revels in the intricate tapestry of history or happens to masochistically enjoy the labyrinthine intricacies of a game that is engineered to confound, then this experience could be your historical opus. For the rest of us mere mortals, it is a perplexing journey into antiquity, laden with tactical enigmas and a generous helping of the toga going on.

The mechanics are more refined and the balance is much better between factions. It was interesting clawing my way up as an upstart Iceni clan, each of the surrounding factions refusing trade. I systematically waged war and eliminated every single faction in the British isles, then quickly expanded trade, farming and military industries and attacked the mainland along several points. That was the beginning of our empire, now stretching from Ireland to Sparta and making a fortune in trade and agriculture. It is always inspiring to see my battle hardened troops cheering as the enemy is routing and trampled by cavalry. Go now, to your bloody business!

Edit in 2023: I am still playing this game every so often, it`s only improved with time and the mods make it one of the best Total Wars especially when compared to Warhammer. I love Troy too, but Rome II still just sits atop the historical Total Wars now.

Recommended ONLY with Divide et Impera mod (available through Steam workshop). Without this mod Rome ii, even with all its updates, remains mediocre and less interesting than some of the other Total War titles (i.e Shogun 2). With the Divide et Impera mod this game is highly recommended for those that are interested in this time period. Lots of historical context is provided in the event, location and unit descriptions. Note that most of the DLC add value by unlocking more factions and campaigns in the Divide et Impera mod.

I keep coming back to this entry a lot more than other total war titles, such as Medieval 2, Shogun 2, and Empire just for the political and diplomacy systems. I enjoy playing on very hard difficulty but I can't stand the whole of the world declaring war on me for no discernible reason. The AI diplomatic actions make more sense and the political system prevents you from expanding too fast due to the potential for civil war. You can't just raise armies, take a few countries, and steamroll the world. You have to constantly monitor the political situation which I love. I hope future entries continue to include these aspects of the game.

I realised I never wrote a review for this game despite having owned it since release and liking it a lot so here we go.

To start off, Rome 2 has always been a positive experience from me even during the arguably shoddy launch. I didn't really have any issues during the launch of the game but over the years it's grown better with the latest addition of the much wanted family tree. I've been a huge Total War fan since Medieval 1(give us medieval 3 already!!!) and I'm honestly yet to be disappointed in a main game of the franchise(I don't consider Attila and Britannia to be "main" games and I haven't tried them). 

Rome 2 does scratch my Roman era itch where the design of units etc looks pretty much as I prefer them. I prefer the lorica segmenta full "hollywood" look compared to the more "realistic" mail looks some mods for this game encourage. I can't really comment on barbarians, but playing Rome is great in this game, as is playing most civilized nations. Campaign map is great and still holds up fine despite having seen improvements in both Warhammer and Three Kingdoms. Battles are not as great but they're okay imo and still fun. It gets better again in Three Kingdoms so I'm happy CA is reverting to their more "old" ways there. This should make for a good MTW3! ;)

Rome 2 is a fine game but Medieval 3 will be better!

This game certainly had a very rocky release back in 2013, and deservedly so, it received very mixed reviews. Fast forward ten years however, this game has had a degree of polish which I believe has made it a decent, overall entry to the total war series. Although it certainly cannot match up to Rome 1 or Medieval 2, this is an aesthetically pleasing and very re-playable game, with greatly varied factions and a comparatively large number of DLC campaigns, with 'Rise of the Republic' being the bets of the bunch (in my opinion). This game certainly has it's flaws and several irritatingly clumsy campaign mechanics that cannot be fixed, such as diplomacy and the faction politics, but overall it reasonably well balanced and enjoyable, both on the battle and campaign map.

I like it, but I have some misgivings. This isn't helped by the fact it took me a good 80 hours just to finish one campaign. That length of time can make one grow irritated at certain features, so bear that in mind. 

[b]It's a bit rinse and repeat-y.[/b]
Fight the battle. Form your lines. Send cavalry off to fight ranges units or into the backs of the enemy's lines. When they collapse, play the fun game of selecting cavalry units and trying to click on the routing enemies to mop them up.

The battles ARE good and this is an oversimplified look at them, but sadly this is more or less how it goes, no matter your opponent, no matter where you are. Admittedly, it may be very different if you play as different factions as not everyone has the heavy infantry of Rome. I may find out one day but for now I need a break.

[b]The army structure is too strict, and this causes problems.[/b]
You make an army by starting with a general, who then spawns an army with 19 additional slots which you recruit units to.
You recruit units into this army. You do NOT recruit units from settlements (despite the fact that it's your infrastructure that dictates which units you can have). Your units CANNOT leave your armies except from being disbanded or by being handed over to another army standing right next to their current army
The number of armies you can raise is driven directly by how your "Imperium" level - which is an artificial difficulty system meant to make the game harder to manage the further you progress. 

On the plus side, it means there's less scrappy armies bumbling around like you'd see in other TW games - you (and the AI) are forced to build big, tall armies.

So why is this a problem? [b]You have NO flexibility.[/b] You conquer a settlement. You move forward. An enemy army can just walk out of the fog of war and walk into your settlement [i]without even fighting you[/i] and take it off you. This is relentlessly frustrating. Your settlements have NO garrison until you've rebuilt their buildings - which can take a handful of turns. Even if you don't sack the settlement, you need to rebuild the whole lot because it's the wrong culture so it doesn't work for you. So you're supposed to just have your army squat there until it's ready to go before moving on? How incredibly dull.

Oh well, I'll just leave behind a token force who can catch up later, right? That's how it works in other TW games, right? Wrong. As I said, your units cannot leave your army. You can't leave any of them behind. It's your whole army or sweet FA guarding that town until a garrison appears after you've rebuilt it. It essentially increases the amount of armies you need in order to go forth and conquer.

And those garrisons are incredibly small. The garrison is almost the same between a basic city and a level 5 one but even a fully developed city can have fewer units than a half-stack army and half of those are basically unarmoured, useless plebs/mob. There's no point to them. Basically if the AI shows up with one large army with a reasonable arrangement of units, they'll outnumber you 2:1 with better units and you don't stand a chance. If we had access to a middleweight-tier militia arrangement it might be a lot better. At the moment your garrison is one strong unit, 2-3 decent units and the rest is rabble.

So why the thumb up? It is a good game, there's lots of unit variety and some of my issues look like they can be fixed with mods. I've only tried vanilla so far, and I know this is an old game that'll never get patched and for all I know, more recent titles in the series fix a lot of this but here's what I'd do with this game to fix it:

1. Allow garrison recruitment on a city level. I'm making 60k a turn, I'll happily spend a few thousand on the odd garrison near my borders. I'm not even talking about troops that I can order to leave the city or wander around. Just troops who form a garrison and stay there until I disband them.

2. Bring back the Man of the Hour mechanic. I know this doesn't work in a game where armies aren't allowed to exist without a general, but if cities can build their own garrisons (see point 1) then maybe? At the moment you have to play the family sim minigame and make sure everyone gets married asap and starts having kids. This wasn't impressed upon with such importance in the tutorial so I ignored it for the first 60 turns of my first campaign as the menu was confusing. Regretted it because my political party ran low on generals, meaning the other parties had more generals, which allowed them to become quite influential. It's better if this doesn't happen! Anyway I digress.

3. Rework some of the other types of battles. Earlier I mentioned that the battles can be repetitive. This is true, but there are a multitude of types of battles in this game which is a welcome innovation. You could be storming a makeshift fort/camp, you could be ambushing your enemy who are in a disorganised marching column, but 99% of the time... you're just sieging a city or fighting on the plains in a standard lineup. Perhaps that's just me, but there is still room for variety I think. It would certainly help the tedium if city garrisons could be more varied and just bigger, as stated. 

4. I know this one's literally me saying "do more work!" but I think that's acceptable here. Please, this game needs more battle maps. Uncanny that every settlement of a given type happens to look the same. It makes the fights all the more repetitive when not only is the town the same shape, layout and size, but so is the surrounding terrain. I can probably count the number of different town fighting maps I recall fighting on, on one hand. That's kinda bad, guys, because you need to conquer nearly a hundred of these things to win a standard game. Earlier titles had cool features like being able to see other cities or islands in the distance, depending on the nearby geography. Compared to that, this just feels a bit rushed.

It's a good game. I'd say get it on sale if you're interested.

My thoughts on this game 

I am aware at first this game got knocked for removing gameplay elements and mechanics from previous total wars, to be fair that was to fix a bug in the engine they were using. The game was also knocked for it's removal of content to sell as dlc and it's bad graphics at first launch. However, The Creative Assembly fixed all that in a timely manner and made the game even better. The dlcs are good as well. The game is historically accurate and faithful to the series and to the scenario it's set in. The graphics are still passable even today. The gameplay is fun. CA fixed the launch problems. The modding community is still active with one of the greatest total war mods of all time. 

pros 
CA fixed the complaints and bugs 
the modding tools were freely given out 
the graphics and units are beautiful 
the world is accurate 
the mechanics are good 
the dlcs are good 

cons 
CA removed the ability to mod the map 
All the minor factions are copy pastes of each other 

overall a solid 8 out 10. The graphics and gameplay are good, but most of the content is only for the playable countries and CA took huge series changing steps that took us a bit to get used too.

EDIT

The recent update has rendered the game unplayable even on my high end PC because of the new extreme unit lagging making battles impossible to play which persists even after disabling all mods and going to lowest settings. shame on you CA for ruining one of your best games.
