After many years of playing the game and reading/watching critiques of it, I thought I'd put my two cents in. I'm not going to list pros and cons, as I've noticed that some of these might be pretty subjective, and instead I'll touch upon several aspects of the game from different perspectives. For context, this game was released 9 years after the original Rome, 4 years after Empire and two years after Shogun 2. A lot of people somehow expected Rome 2 to be a modded version of the original Rome (like Europa Barbarorum) with better graphics, completely ignoring that CA were on a different trajectory for many years already (although I do think that they used some ideas from the mods when fleshing out the unit rosters). To me it was less of a surprise to see some features that were already present in Empire (a fun and ambitious game, but hilariously, embarrassingly bad and buggy at times) and Shogun 2 (that was put on a pedestal by the community), including, but not limited to, issues with unit mass, limited building slots and questionable DLC practices.

At this point I think there's something like 8 different campaigns, all of which feature a variety of factions in different starting positions in terms of size or geographical locations. I like that the grand campaign includes East Africa, Arabia and Central Asia. You can see that the Greek cities (possibly for balance reasons) are not very well fleshed out there, but they are much more detailed in both Wrath of Sparta and Rise of the Republic.

I do like the province system of the game and it feels neat to me when I obtain control of a whole province, although I get that someone else might see this as railroading. It would've been good to be able to set taxes per province, for example. A population mechanic is also missing, although it was terribly balanced in the original Rome. The province edicts compensate a little bit for that lost complexity, but not much.

The building system in Rome 2 is criticized for two things: its representation through icons and the limited building slots. I think it's good that the game forces you to think what building is best to put in your precious building slot, where you have to consider the state of the entire province. This limitation is compensated by two things: the variety of resource buildings and the factions' unique final buildings, which also help to shake up the building icons a little bit. I think the resource buildings and especially the final buildings could have been utilized much more in the game in order to increase its replayability. One thing that I find annoying (especially when coming back from Attila) is the lack of a building browser. There was an encyclopedia but at some point it was removed.

There's plenty of events, wonders, politics and diplomacy, which are all nice. One thing that's missing from the game is figuring out some form of different playstyle for the nomadic factions. I think that, overall, the current politics system is great, and I love that the foreign diplomacy action can get you a settlement for free. Some people would be unpleasantly surprised when their character gets killed on a mission. However, if you were to send someone to a foreign country, would it be your son and heir, or someone more disposable?

The traits are often cited as an example of Rome 2's lack of soul in comparison with the original game, which is ironic given the amount of effort the developers have seemingly put into creating Rome 2's trait system. Rome 2 has plenty of traits, but they are presented in a different way from Rome 1. Some traits are gained by the characters on their own, but most of them are selected by the player when they level on. Depending on your playstyle, all your characters would end up having the same traits, as there is one build that you would consider to be the best, or rather the most practical one. I think it's a difficult thing to get right. The issue with the retinue and household is that they are presented by icons that you don't really understand and you only get what they mean once you mouse over them. These icons are a part of the core feel of the game together with the unit cards, so it's a take it or leave it sort of situation.

Speaking of the unit cards, they got a lot of hate ever since the release of the game. It was fairly ambitious of CA to radically change something that was a core aspect of Total War and completely depart from what they had done on every other game before or since. The issue is that with this Greek pottery style it may be very difficult to distinguish between units, some of which might be already very similar to each other in terms of where they fit on the roster. This might be an issue if you need to look at the unit cards during a battle in a situation where you might have to react quickly on focus on the battle itself. Personally, I find them immersive and aesthetically pleasing, and I don't mind looking at them from time to time.

You may notice that my review is mostly concentrated on the campaign, as I have few things to say about the battles that haven't been said already. To me all Total War battles are kind of similar and I can't not notice how all games since Empire have been impacted by this same engine, so I don't think there's anything sticking out in Rome 2 in particular. If you are playing a campaign on higher difficulties, you will notice how missile troops become more important as melee tactics become irrelevant due to AI bonuses. As I mostly play on Normal, this doesn't impact me at all. As people are still playing Rome 2 multiplayer 10 years after its release, the battles as an aspect of the game are obviously appealing to enough players, although the rosters feature many units that seemingly differ very little in function and have similar unit cards. As I mostly play the campaigns, I love that Roman units can be retrained into different ones, both in the grand campaign and in Rise of the Republic, it's just something that feels satisfying. If you only play multiplayer, you will end up wondering what's the deal with all these pointless units. This is something that the developers leaned very heavily into in Attila (to my delight), which is a game that is even less oriented towards multiplayer than Rome.

The naval aspect of the game is it's greatest weak point, I think. If only the transport fleets were handicapped a little more, the players would be more incentivized to develop fleets. I think that in the current state of balance in the game, building fleets is completely pointless and can be ignored without consequences. This problem feeds into two other systems, the buildings and the traits, as I never build military naval buildings, nor do I make my characters into admirals, which limits my game experience. This left me wondering why another naval building was added to Empire Divided, when this core issue remains. I'll admit that the some of the ships look very beautiful. One other thing that turns you off from the naval game is the fact that even when you win a naval battle, you can still easily lose a ship. I don't know about you, but I often like to keep all of my original units during my campaigns as they are something like my children.

The soundtrack of Rome 2 is often compared negatively to the one of Rome 1. I think it's pretty okay, I definitely wouldn't listen to it for fun with the exception of two tracks: Hunters, which has kind of a mystical Barbarian forest thing going on ( at least in my imagination), and Goddess of the River Nile, which is a gorgeous and rich representation of the splendor of Cleopatra's Egypt. Not the real Cleopatra's Egypt, mind you, but a classic Hollywood film set in it. I think it represents Rome 2 as a game: big, bloated and flawed, but it sure is beautiful.

TLDR: I've played more than a thousand hours of this when I could've done anything else with my life. Two thumbs up!

I can't recommend this Triple AAA trash. CA has abandoned this game as the MASSIVE amount of bugs and broken game mechanics have not been fixed in the past DECADE... its been 10 years and they still haven't done anything except downgrade this game by taking away multiplayer chat. !!HEAD TO BOTTOM FOR FINAL THOUGHTS!!

Buying the game itself does not give you the full experience as half the factions are locked behind a paywall and crashes are a normal occurrence. Every time I play a game and exit it completely Shuts down my computer and freezes it. My computer is top of the line and I used to play this game on an old potato of a computer and the graphics only slightly improved while the crashes stayed the same.

Problems START:
Bugs relating to interface with letters being invisible and certain backgrounds turning invisible (makes it hard to see anything)

Soldier unit placement doesn't always show on elevated areas making it impossible to see formations.

Sometimes Saves are deleted in computer shutdowns when exiting game.

Rome 2 Mission Campaigns are glitchy, broken, crash recurrent, unplayable, worse then Rome 1 Mission Campaigns (which came out 20 years ago and works well for its time)

Faction diversity is bland where everyone has the same Roster/Settlement system as the Romans from Scythians to Africans.

Multiplayer duels/campaigns have a high rate of crashing early to late game with random lag spikes from different types of internet so it doesn't matter if you have good or bad internet. (I've played about 30 hours of multi)

Unit Pathing is buggy and broken especially in naval as naval units don't listen to orders most of the time.

AI is the same through all difficulties just making it harder for you to use the interface and politics just turns into civil wars every 10 turns.

The DLC's don't add much except for a new starting area of the map with some new units. The Blood DLC is basically required if you want the Rome experience even though it should have been in the base game, Although the DLC it self is broken where if your unit comes into contact with another unit for a second half your troops will be completely bloody as if they went through minutes of fighting. 

A lot of game mechanics from the original Rome 1 were taken out of the game like soldiers standing to the side letting other troops through unlike the lazy version in Rome 2 which just bumps your troops around a lot and traps your troops sometimes in another unit. 

Problems ENDED:

That's all I can say for now cause I may have forgotten some other problems with this game.

This game is not worth $70 and most of it's DLC's are essential for the Rome 2 experience and should be part of the main game. The games worth less then a bag of potatos. All the hours I've played I had some fun moments but after a while I got bored because its really bland and the bugs are everywhere. It's more healthy and stress free to watch videos of this game then play it.

CA is trash, Rome 2 Sucks, I hope their Greedy Corporate hands don't ruin Rome 3 or Medieval 3 or Empire 3.

Own a Gladius for home defense, since that is what the founders of Rome intended. Four plebeians break into my home. "By Jove!" as I replace my Toga with a Galea and grab my Pila and Gladius. Leave a golf ball sized wound in the first man, he is dead on the spot. Throw my other Pilum at the second man, miss him entirely because he is too far and nail the neighbour's dog. I have to resort to the Onager at the top of the stairs loaded with pots of Greek Fire, "Roma Invicta!" as the Greek Fire burns two men to a crisp, the roaring sound and out of control fire sucking up all the oxygen. Strap my Scutum to my arm and charge the last terrified plebeian. He bleeds out waiting for the police to arrive since Gladius wounds are impossible to stitch up. Just as the founders of Rome intended.
What can I say ... it's a classic ... must play at least once ... and then try all the other Factions

I can't recommend the game in the current state for several reasons, even though it's a Total War game, and I really want to like it.

1) The devs push out updates to literally remove features like chat and break all mods again in the process.
2) This game is very hard to mod properly and even if you're careful, you never know if bugs or performance problems are creeping into a long strategic campaign, which is supposed to be the core of the game.
3) AI is extremely flat and doesn't even build out its territory properly in the base game. Look at the Second Triumvirate as Pompey Sextus if you have the game or can. A classic example and what really convinced me on this point is seeing how Octavian didn't even upgrade his starting area--ridiculous. Basically, if you survive the first 30 turns of most campaigns, there isn't much real opposition after that if you do an actual build.
4) I am beyond sick of companies that do whatever they can to crush gaming and take the fun out of it. They even had the audacity to recommend that people move to Discord when it is closed source (enjoy being spied on 24/7) and doesn't have freedom of speech on it. I guess letting people chat with their friends is automatically wrongthink now or whatever--I don't keep up with it, but I sure can't stand the behavior.

Sometimes the pieces just don't come together.  This isn't a [i]bad[/i] game, I mean, it's still a Total War title, and it is Imperial Rome. It's just that the ingredients never seem to gel.  From the somewhat drab color scheme (seriously, the legionaries armor looks brown), to the uninspiring character portraits, to the progressively tedious gameplay, there's something about Rome II that doesn't spark joy. 

Flawed as it was, Rome: Total War had a zany energy that pulled you onward.  What energy there is to Rome II burns out after turn 50 when the game essentially becomes a poor Paradox grand strategy, because who's personally fighting battles after turn 50?  What at first seemed like strengths of the new game, like the immense map, quickly became insufferable ("where am I in generic central Asia?  I don't even care anymore...")  Or the way-too-long endgame victory conditions requiring ridiculous grinds of conquest and logistical contortions that no halfway decent player would consider: field 40 mercenary units?  Maintain 60 naval units in a game where naval combat is totally, and thankfully avoidable?  Economic and cultural victories that require random territory conquests on the other side of the map that your supply lines could never keep up with?  Add to this an Imperium system that makes each successive conquest  more about spreadsheet micromanagement and diminishing returns than, um, Total War...  And a political and character management system with 15 options of which only 2 are ever available?  

My Carthage campaign on N/N was a feat of endurance rather than a labor of love.  I wanted this game to be an overlooked gem.  It's not.  Pick it up on sale and prove me wrong.  But if you want to actually have fun, pick up Attila (with AoC, preferably) or Warhammer II and knock yourself out. At best B- gaming from a franchise of literal legends.

I am a casual gamer and I've put what I consider to be a good amount of time into this game over the years. I love the Total War historical series and I own most of them. However, as of recently, almost every one of them has ceased to work for me. I have a good computer, 3070 ti, 16 gb of ram, decent CPU. At the very least enough to get into a custom battle. Now, for most of the Total War games, I have crashes through any campaign, battle, or start screen I go to. To me, the game is unplayable and it's frustrating to waste the few hours I have clean installing and troubleshooting constantly. I've read many discussion posts in each of the Total War games so I know I am not alone in this problem. I hope one day they fix this issue, but until that day it's just not worth the time to keep coming back to them.

Buy at your own risk. I didn't see any reviews recently mentioning this problem so I figured I'd leave one as a warning to potential buyers. There is a good possibility the game just won't run.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I played this game for a few years and it has never failed me. I know a lot of people who hate this game, but I don't have too much bad to say. The factions are good, the family tree is decent, everything seems to be for the most part historically accurate. The battles are (for me at least) very fun to play especially with the music. The diplomacy really is awful and needs improvement and the secession from you is the most annoying thing ever, but other than that, this is a great game. I would say that this is my 2nd favourite total war game, after of course, Shogun 2 (cause of the Cavalry). Would definitely recommend buying this game, along with Shogun 2 and also Atilla (not as good but still fun to play as the Huns :D).

With a decently low system requierments and an above average campaign, Rome 2 isnt Creative
Assemblys best game, but it isnt their worst either. In general the game is Atilla but with a better historical time period and easier campaign mechanics.

This game is playable with Mods.  I've had fun with the realism mods like RTR and DEI.  The CAI is lacking in a big way as it engages in total war by spamming multiple small armies that sack your town when your armies are not near.  Dealing with a few large scale, well-build armies is great fun.  Dealing with hordes of small stupid armies is not fun, it's tiring.  

CA has a long standing tradition of abandoning beloved games in the series, so if you're going to pick this up make sure to try out some mods as the base game is lacking.  Perhaps when CA is no loner drunk on the spirits of Fantasy and re-skinned sagas, then maybe in a not too distant decade they will return to the strategy world and leave behind the micro management of spells and equipment stats that belong in World of Warcraft.

Seriously, Troy and Pharaoh could have been 1 game with slightly increased scope to fully capture the bronze age.  Instead we get two re-skinned "saga" versions of Three Kingdoms complete with all the Fxxkery us fine strategos have come to loath.

As someone who has played the first Rome, I can say that Rome 2 is very enjoyable and improves upon its predecessor. I love that there are multiple settlements in a province and you can upgrade or specialize each settlement according to your preferences. Most importantly, the AI has notably improved by a lot. I have most of the DLCs so I am not sure if that contributes at all to the AI, but I have noticed the AI smartly keeps spearmen in reserve and prioritizes cavalry whereas the old Rome AI can be easily baited into chasing skirmishers. In addition, the campaign map AI is also pretty realistic. When you are conquering factions and getting powerful, they will trip over each other to start non aggression pacts and alliances with you. They also start ganging up on factions that you have whittled down their strength and settlements. Some of them have annoyingly taken the last settlement that I wanted to complete a province or to destroy a faction myself. Annoying but smart on their part. Great game!!

Total War Rome II - Emperor Edition stands as a shining testament to the grandeur and depth of historical strategy games. With its immersive gameplay, meticulous attention to detail, and a wealth of content, this epic title places players in the heart of ancient Rome, commanding vast armies and shaping the fate of empires. From the breathtaking battles to the intricate diplomacy, Total War Rome II - Emperor Edition offers an unparalleled experience that will captivate strategy enthusiasts and history buffs alike. Prepare to rewrite the annals of history and lead Rome to glory!

Here is a short list of popular features that I believe enhance the gameplay and elevate the experience to new heights:

1. Massive, Cinematic Battles: Witness the spectacle of history come alive as armies clash on a colossal scale. Total War Rome II - Emperor Edition delivers breathtaking battles with thousands of soldiers engaged in epic warfare. From meticulously rendered units to dynamic combat mechanics, each clash feels immersive and strategic. Take command of your forces, deploy cunning tactics, and relish the satisfaction of victory or the sting of defeat in these monumental engagements.

2. Intricate Diplomacy and Politics: Delve into the intricate web of diplomacy and politics as you navigate the treacherous landscape of ancient Rome. Forge alliances, negotiate treaties, and manipulate rival factions to secure your empire's prosperity. Total War Rome II - Emperor Edition offers a depth of diplomatic gameplay that allows you to shape the geopolitical landscape and exert your influence over the world. Master the art of negotiation and tact to ensure the survival and expansion of your empire.

3. Vast Campaign Map and Faction Variety: Embark on a strategic journey across a vast campaign map that spans the ancient world, from the sprawling cities of Rome to the exotic landscapes of distant civilizations. Total War Rome II - Emperor Edition offers a rich variety of playable factions, each with its own unique units, strengths, and challenges. Whether you lead the mighty Roman legions, command barbarian hordes, or seek to restore the glory of forgotten empires, the diverse factions provide endless replayability and strategic depth.

With its monumental battles, intricate diplomacy, and expansive campaign map, Total War Rome II - Emperor Edition stands as a testament to the genre of historical strategy games. Immerse yourself in the grandeur of ancient Rome, and experience the thrill of building and conquering empires in this unparalleled strategy masterpiece.

There's a lot to say about this game. If you give it time you appreciate it a lot more; it seems overly complicated at first, and the battles are hard to understand, but it's very unique and I've never really played a game that can compare to it, in the way that it combines a civ clone tactical overview with a general's viewpoint of a battle. 
The battles are easily the redeeming part of the game; skillfully outmanuevering your opponent and executing a devestating charge that makes his troops break and run, is the most satisfying thing you could experience in a game. They are a bit glitchy, though, and the AI is way too good in some places, and completely clueless in others. In a way, it's more realistic than it wants to be: communication in an army was often not a sure thing, and sometimes a unit or an entire wing would be operating on different information than the others. 
The vanilla game is kinda frustrating; I recommend a 4 turns per year mod, an agent removal mod, and a civil war removal mod at the very least. There are also so excellent unit packs out there that really expand the game. 
As for the game as a whole, this is definitely a scholar's game; it rewards tactical thinking, and punishes tunnel visioning. Moving your armies on the tactical map requires a lot of careful thought; losing a city you thought was safe is really frustrating and will happen unless you're a god at diplomacy (diplomacy is also kinda stupidly done, not a huge fan but it's ok I guess). This game will teach you a bit of stuff about cultural and military history, in a fun way that puts you into the mindset of a conqueror during these periods of expansion and attrition. 
I would say it's a buy on sale. Definitely check out mods to get the most mileage out of this game. I've played three campaigns to completion and I'm on my 4th.

I suppose it's time to review Rome 2. I've had it since releases and I've played it more than any other title--I just passed 1,000 hours. I can hardly criticize the product given the time spent with it. 

The game was porked when it was first released, but CA did a great job fixing it. I have to say that given its age, Rome 2 srtill looks pretty good. There's something epic about the scale of the map, the era, and the powers involved. 

The main reasons I still play, of course, are the Mods. Many are good, some are fantastic. I've probably spent most of my time teh last several years playing DEI and 1100 AD, the Medieval Mod. I recommend them both to anyone looking for a great Mod for Rome 2. 

It says a lot to me that after 1,000 hours I'm still learning things about Rome 2. There's so much going on in the game, and even more with the Mods. That'as why I keep coming back to it. 

How can I complain? I've spend about $150 on the game and the DLCs, most of which were picked up on sale. That comes out to about 15 cents per hour of entertainment. 

Another plus is that since the next TW game is going to be Pharaoh, I expect that development on my two favorite Mods, DEI and 1100 AD will continue.

Why is it people in multiplayer keep picking siege battle and burdigala as the map to play? It has many issues that other maps have like the fact towers are so fucking shit and bug out so often where they just freeze over nothing, can't be placed any closer than 1km away from the other towers and overall is so shit to play because artillery is so innacurate you can only break one wall with all the ammo it has (and I know there is manual aim, but it isn't much more accurate and is really slow since it only lets you shoot one of the 4 artillery units, instead of letting you shoot each one manually in succession to let you properly control them, which is a massive nerf to manual aim) which doesn't leave you much room to push in. every time I played this shitty fucking map nobody got past the defence's defence, this game is overall heavily defender sided as the positional advantage you have is immense and the asymmetrical money they give to attacker's to compensate is often not enough.

Why is it so difficult to make your units move the way you ask them to? In this game, when you right click it quick places the units where you clicked usually facing the enemy, that's fine. When you hold right click tho, many issues arise, as you hold right click, sometimes the right click automatically unholds the button which makes the game think you simply right clicked, and when this happens multiple times in a row it leads to way longer placement times. or longer time to properly make your formation before the battle begins. this has been often detrimental to me as I see my opponent coming for a charge and I want to rotate my units and adjust their width in a quick fashion to properly tank the charge. In this game you can also hold alt or control to move the units you selected as a whole in a fixed manner, very neat feature, makes atilla shit just because it doesn't have this feature. However, when there is any form of terrain that one of the units can't be on, for example a hill in between the formation where you try to go, or a rock, instead of moving individual people within a unit to shape them around the rock, it will push the whole unit out to a location you don't want just so they are all in a valid location, which ruins the formation.
On the note of formations, why is it that when a unit gets pushed, the game doesn't save the placement that the units had, in their formation, before I ordered them to go to an partially invalid location, this would allow for me to finalyl go into forests, which often misplace units for some fucking reason and which fucks up the formation, which then means you have to manually fix it if you want to come out of that forest in formation.
This previous example wouldn't be that bad, if when units are ordered to move in formation, over a flat surface they wouldn't fuck up the formations just like that until they reach their destination, which means selecting them all and rotating them to brace for a surprise cavalry or chariot charge is impossible, this is probably due to the fact, that even in walk mode, when you tell your whole formation to advance, THEY ALL MOVE AT THEIR OWN FUCKING SPEED . they should obviously adjust their speed to the slowest so that all of them hold perfect formation even as they go around, to allow for quick repositionning, and if someone has artillery slowing down their formation, then let them manually tell it to go somewhere and control the rest of the formation where they will probably go at the archer's speed since they are often the second slowest unit 
I think this change should also apply to running units, to avoid my cavalry general running head first into the enemy territory, just let the players who want those units to go faster control them manually.

Why is it when i try to place my units in a cramped space, it often bugs out and places them in totally wrong positions, this wouldn't be so bad, IF EVERYONE DIDN'T FUCKING PLAY SIEGE DAY AND NIGHT WHERE ALL THE STREETS ARE CRAMPED AND OFTEN MAKE PLACING UNITS A HEADACHE, THIS ISNT SO BAD FOR THE DEFENDER WHO PREPLACED HIS UNITS DURING PLACEMENT PHASE BUT VERY FUCKING SHIT FOR THE ATTACKER THAT OFTEN NEEDS TO OUT MICRO THE ENEMY DEFENDER TO BE ABLE TO PRESSURE MORE THAN ONE UNIT WHILE HAVING HIS UNITS FACE THE RIGHT WAY DURING THEIR CHARGE INSTEAD OF FACING RANDOM WALLS, HONESTLY I DONT KNOW HOW TO FIX THIS ISSUE CUZ I AINT ONE OF THEIR SHITTY CODERS THAT MADE THE MAIN FUCKING GAMEMODE SO FUCKING CANCER TO PLAY, EVERY TIME I PLAY A SIEGE BATTLE I HAVE A PROBLEM WITH HTE PLACEMENT OF MY UNITS THAT COSTS ME MY TROOPS, FOR EXAMPLE, LETS SAY I BROKE A WALL IN BURDIGALA, I TELL MY UNIT TO PUSH TO THE RIGHT OF THAT WALL TO ATTACK SOME ENEMIES, WHILE THAT HAPPENS, I TELL ARCHERS TO GET ON THE WALL, THEY DO SO, BUT THEY ARE LOCKED FACING OUTWARD OF THE CITY INSTEAD OF INWARD, WHICH MEANS, I CAN'T ASK THEM TO SHOOT THE ENEMY UNIT FROM THE SIDE, SINCE THEY ARE SO FUCKING RETARDED AND CAN'T MOVE FOR SHIT ALONG A WALL AND ATTACK AN ENEMY, THIS ALSO HAPPENS WITH MELEE UNITS, WHICH IS WHY I HATE FUCKING GETTING ON THE WALLS, BUT OBVIOUSLY EVERYONE PLAYS  WITH THE RULE: 1 artillery 2 pikes 4 missile units max, WHICH MEANS I ONLY BREAK ONE WALL SINCE I ONLY HAVE 1 ARTILLERY  AND CAN BARELY GET MY UNITS PAST IT SINCE THEY KEEP BODY BLOCKING EACH OTHER NATURALLY, CUZ MOVING YOUR WHOLE ARMY THROUGH ONE TINY HOLE ISN'T VERY EFFICIENT.
Also for Burdigala, why is it that when i break the wall, it pours down dirt that I can make my unit go through, but I can't tell my units to place themselves on that dirt hill to protect, FOR EXEMPLE, FROM A CAVALRY CHARGE COMING FROM ONE OF MANY IMPENETRABLE DOORS WITH WAY TOO FUCKING MANY FIRETOWERS AROUND IT AND A HILL AFTER THAT ENSURES THAT EVEN IF YOU GET PAST THE DOOR, YOU GET FUCKED BY YOUR REDUCED UNIT'S UPHILL CHARGE SPEED. ALSO, MAYBE TO BALANCE THAT MAP, REMOVE OIL FROM THE GATEHOUSES ON IT? AN IDEA FOR YOU MORONS WHO MADE THEM IMPENETRABLE AND A PERFECT PLACE FOR THE DEFENDERS TO PULL OUT THEIR CHARIOTS OR CAVALRY FROM.

NOW FINALLY, FOR MY LAST GROIP WITH THE GAME, WHY IS IT THAT WHEN I PREPLACE MY ARCHERS FACING THE CHARIOTS OR CAVALRY THAT IS ABOUT TO CHARGE THEM, THEY DONT SHOOT? What I mean is I told my archers to face the incoming cavalry or chariot charge as they are the best units to deal with them, since they are basically invincible to most other units for some fucking reason, and I DOUBLE right clicked the incoming charge when they were in range (note: I always have guard mode on and remove fire at will on archers) they didnt shoot, instead they looked at them, and after 5 seconds pulled out their daggers, just so they can get fucked royally. and when that isn't what happens, THEY REPOSITION, AS IF THEY WERENT ALREADY FACING THE ENEMY, why? why? why? can't they just let fucking loose like they do in other instances where they fuck my cavalry? WHAT SECRET AM I MISSING PEOPEL THAT MAKES THEM FUCKING SHOOT, I DOUBLE RIGHT CLICKED WHEN THE CAVALRY JUST GO INTO RANGE!!! I GAVE THEM MAXIMAL TIME TO THROW THEIR VOLLEY, AT LEAST THE PEOPLE THAT HAVE DIRECT LINE OF SIGHT, AT THE FRONT, WITH THE CAV SHOULDA FIRED.
WHY DO ARCHERS IN THIS GAME SHOOT SOMETIMES AT THE FUCKING SKY 80 DEGREES UP TO SHOOT YOUR UNIT THAT IS TRY TO HIDE AGAINST THE WALL OF THE HOUSES ON THE OTHER STREET? WHY ARE THEY SO GOOD AT THAT BUT NOT AT SHOOTING UP TOWARDS DEFENDER'S ARCHERS WHICH HAVE SUCH A FUCKING EASY SHOT? WHY CAN THEY NTO SHOOT PEOPLE RIGHT IN FRONT OF THEM AND DECIDE TO LOITER AND STAND STILL AS THEY SEE ANY UNIT CHARGING RIGHT INFRONT OF THEM WHICH IS THE EASIEST SHOT OF THEIR LIVES??? BRO FIX YOUR FUCKING ARCHERS CA YOU BASTARDS.

I tried to like it, I got to 180 turns the year it came out, before putting it away for a while. Coming back after a year (or two) there was an overhaul and a balance update in between, all good and well that they want to keep the game balanced and introduce new systems, but I couldn't finish the game I started and there was no way to revert back to an earlier version, because the new balances and events screwed my campaign up so much I basically lost the next turn due to revolts and the resulting downwards spiral.
I tried again a few times on fresh campaigns with different factions but never got far. The cities on their own aren't that useful and you run out of food really quick, while you can't build up enough troops to siege your inferior neighbor. Conquering whole districts is thus a priority, while not always practical. There are some events added in one of the updates for realism sake I guess, which are forced to happen, but not always make sense. 
I feel like they are half going for historical accuracy and realism but that's not what I'm looking for in a war game. I'm just finding myself picking up Rome TW again instead of this, despite the jank of the old game and the better looks of this game.
Edit: Mods make it a lot better, basically it is mediocre and needs work. I can't give it a thumbs up if the community needs to fix a full priced game from a big studio.

Rome 2 is the awkward teenager of the Total War series. It had outgrown the niche strategy of the classic era, and went through some major teething issues on its way to the AAA grand strategy it is today. Despite this, it's an excellent game today, with years of love put into it. It has a whopping EIGHT campaigns (if I remember correctly), making it the premier strategy game for any fans of Antiquity.

I love the total war series, I really do but I can't recommend this game.  Sure it looks nice and to be the leader of Rome is a lot of fun but the game is so poorly managed that it's hard to ever see it making a proper recovery.  The release of "DLC" while the features of the game itself were not completely or properly functioning was a disgrace.  We got an Alpha version of Rome II and it showed.  Feature wise we got some nice new bits and some great new graphics but is it a major improvement over Rome Total War?  Considering they are now releasing DLC for the same types of features and cultures that were in the original I'm pretty disappointed.  In some areas Rome II is an improvement, but for the most part, it's a major step back.  After the disaster that was the Empire Total War release I avoided Shogun II for a long, long time.  Whatever comes after Rome II is going to have to do a lot better to convince me even try it.

EDIT: After several years and now revisiting this game, I can say it is now complete. Sadly I still think it is amongst the weakest of the Total War series. Too many limitations and there is somehow, after many DLCs and patches, still a lack of depth to the game.

WARNING: CAESAR DLC IS COMPLETE WASTE OF $15

I really wanted to like this game. I even still find myself playing it from time to time. The original Rome Total War not only got me into strategy games but started my obsession with Roman history. When they announced this game I was on the CA page waiting for every bit of coverage. 

After playing since release, I have come to terms with how monotinously boring it is. The tech tree, the province system, the trait system, land plotting system, general creation, spy/dignitary/veteran system are all designed to add content to the game. Unfortunately, all that these features really do is take away from the abstracted depth that the original had. Everything feels too much like a todo list that takes too much work to navigate through.  

Another issue I have is the ridiculous amount of tiny factions. Not only do they make waiting for the next turn a chore, they remove all sense of there being an epic war between nations. Often I'm thinking 'OK time to take out these guys.' Later game doesn't have this problem but by then (especially if you are Rome, Greece, Egypt, or Seleucid) you are practically invincible. The late game is not only annoyingly time consuming due to all the menus you have to click through, it isn't even worth playing due to the balance issues...

The DLC for this game is the most absurd thing I've ever seen from CA. I had to pay 3.00 just to have blood and gore in a game about sending massive armies of melee troops at each other? Really, CA? And the Caesar in Gaul campaign is a joke. It's the same exact thing with a different tech tree, a general named Caesar (and Marc Antony), and a few extra units. Definitely not worth $15. Really dissapointed by this.

The redundant roman units, slow loading textures, long battle load times, clunky naval battles, over-crowded/sized unit grouping, boring political system(the three territory system of the original was much better), frustrating multiplayer campaign system, completely unbalanced campaign(which is expected but still pretty excessive... Egypt), awkward campaign camera, and unatractive UI are just a few more of the things that make this game an epic failure. 

In fact, I can't think of a single thing about this game that I liked that Rome 1 didn't do just as well, if not better. Even the graphics engine isn't properly optimized to look relatively decent on my Core i7, Radeon R9 280x machine. I have to stress to anyone who hasn't played the original...

Go play the original Rome: Total War, it is an incredible game that is much more fun than this mess of a project. Hopefully in a couple years Rome 2 will have been modded to the point that it is worth playing again.

After Warhammer III left yet another sour taste in my mouth, I decided to revisit Rome 2 since I hadn't played it in a while and wanted to see if maybe I was burnt out of total war. I started a slightly modded campaign as Macedon on VH and decided to do a WC. I had an absolute blast playing it and it gave me many nostalgic vibes from the campaigns I've played across the years. Personally, I believe that Rome 2 is the crown jewel of total war as I sit here with about 750 hrs making it the #2 most played game on my 9 year old account. It's just a fantastic game and remains one of my all-time favorites. If you want an indepth explanation of why I think it's so good then I'll leave one below, but to sum it up, this game is excellent and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes war games. It's a very easy to learn game and still remains fun on the harder difficulties that I play on.

AI (8/10)
I didn't realize how much better the AI is in this game than the newer games untiI I played Warhammer 3. The AI will regularly attempt to fight your armies, invade you, and likes to put up a fight. I couldn't even tell if this game has an anti-player bias which is shocking when compared to the egregious way the AI behaves in WH 3 (ignoring the 4 stacks bearing down on its country just to raid your settlements). I cannot tell you how refreshing it is to not have the AI constantly moving out of your attack range and instead choosing to sack as many undefended settlements as possible. Of course, the AI isn't amazing but it feels more realistic in this game and less manufactured. In battles, the AI is competent enough to give you a fight. They are fairly predictable but a lot harder to cheese, which makes the battles SO much more enjoyable to play. It's just nice to play against an AI that feels fair rather than an AI that is dumb and manufactured to be aggravating.

Empire Building/Economy/World Map (8/10)
My favorite part of the Total War series is empire building and developing provinces until you can make a super economy and fund elite armies. In Rome 2, that aspect of the game feels great. You can specialize certain provinces to produce certain types of income and build them accordingly to maximize profits. Researching specific technologies may help you in one area, but delay you in another. There are plenty of choices to make when it comes to the economy and what to divert funds to. The AI doesn't straight up refuse to make deals with you and is generally open to trading and alliances. Public order isn't that big of a pain to manage like it is in the newer games and even on the harder difficulties you shouldn't have that much issue managing it. I actually like the fact that you can't permanently remove cultures from the game since that is historically accurate. The vast majority of regions would never be 100% one religion or culture. The food mechanic isn't a massive issue and honestly I kinda like it. With all of that said, Rome 2 has probably the worst mechanic in any total war game which is corruption. I have no idea why they designed corruption to function the way it does with your economy getting worse as your empire expands. You get to the point where it can actually be harmful to expand because the amount of money you lose to corruption is directly related to the amount of provinces you own. It's an awful mechanic that is frustrating to deal with and should have been either tempered or replaced entirely. This section would get a 10 if not for that god awful mechanic and the middling politics system. It's better than it was at launch but is still largely able to be ignored or bought off. All in all, still really fun.

Factions (9/10)
This game has a very good variety of factions that each play differently. The Romans will play completely different than the Parthians for example and don't function the same at all. Most nations will end up have a similar build but the unit variety is wide enough to the point where it's not an issue for me. The only issue I really have with the factions is the fact that the barbarian factions feel very copy-pasted. They all field basically the same unit roster with little to no change which makes it feel kinda eh. Other than that, I enjoyed playing the wide variety of factions Rome 2 gives you. 

Battles (10/10)
This might be a slight hot take, but I absolutely love the battles in this game. I'm not sure if its because I'm writing this review after playing WH 3 whose battles are so atrocious that it makes anything else seem like a ray of sunlight, but the battles in this game are really fun. I found myself actively wanting to play battles in this game even if I could autoresolve them. I love the Roman Era unit design and I thought the weather feature was a great touch. Fighting massive battles in giant rainstorms, the desert, snow covered forests, etc. was extremely fun. Playing differently depending on who I was fighting or fighting as was also fun  (Nomads vs Hellenic as an example). I just found myself always wanting to fight more and to this day I have not had a total war have that effect on me. The unit rosters are massive and there are so many different units you can use and fight against during the course of a campaign.

Graphics + Performance (9/10)
I actually think the graphics for this game have held up pretty well. I genuinely would rather look at this game than WH 3 which is shocking considering this game is almost 10 years older. The only thing that looks kinda weird are the faces of the units. They look like play-doh and look really off. The game runs beautifully and doesn't suffer from the awful performance issues that plague Attila to this day. I've had 1 crash in the past 300-400 hours and 0 glitches. It's just nice playing a game that actually feels finished and bug-free (which is crazy considering the way the game launched) instead of the dumb crap CA puts out nowadays. 

Music (5/10)
Eh, it's alright. I still vastly prefer Rome 1's soundtrack over this one, but it isn't the worst in the world. It isn't annoying like WH 3s is, but it's still rather forgettable. 
 
DLC (7/10)
This will be the first game I've reviewed that does not get a 0 in the DLC category. That is because I actually think the DLC campaigns in this game are extremely good. A large amount of the time I've put into the game was in the DLC campaigns like Empire Divided, RoR, and the like. The unique scenarios that they bring make them, in my opinion, worth buying. You get a good amount of factions even up to 8-10 in some cases and it's like buying a different game. The reason it doesn't get a higher grade is because of the existence of faction packs. I am of the opinion that faction packs are a cash grab and should not exist. Other than that, I think the DLC is actually worth buying and I find myself enjoying those campaigns even more than the main game at times.

Mod Support (10/10)
Rome 2 has arguably the best mod for the post-Shogun 2 era total wars which is DEI. That mod and the amount of work that has gone into it are only truly rivaled by MK 1212 AD for Attila. It expands or overhauls every single feature in the game and floods it with historically accurate units and extremely cool campaign features. Besides that, the game has plenty of mods that customize units, remove bad features (corruption), create a cleaner UI, etc. Plenty of options to create a customized campaign. None of the mods block achievements as well which is a huge added bonus. 
 
Conclusion
Rome 2 remains my favorite total war of all time and one of the best games I've ever played. I love this period in history and I'm glad the game survived it's rough launch 9-10 years ago. It's blossomed into a fantastic game that I enjoy far more than CA's newer products. 

Final Grade - 9/10 - Top-Tier Wargame

Total War™: ROME II - Emperor Edition is a solid entry in the Total War series, offering an engaging strategy experience set in ancient Rome. Despite its age, the game still holds up well with its impressive graphics and improved gameplay mechanics. However, it's worth noting that the game is quite expensive for its age and may be best enjoyed by waiting for a sale. The fact that Sega is still charging a high price for a game that's over a decade old is disappointing and highlights their out of touch pricing strategy. That being said, if you're a fan of the Total War franchise or have an interest in ancient Rome, this game is definitely worth checking out.

Total War™: ROME II - Emperor Edition is a real-time strategy game developed by Creative Assembly and published by Sega. It is the eighth installment in the Total War™ series and was released in 2013.

I personally enjoyed playing Total War™: ROME II - Emperor Edition. The game offers an immersive experience where you can control your own empire and conquer other territories. The game is set in ancient Rome, and the attention to detail in the graphics and sound design is impressive.

One of the aspects of the game that I really liked was the strategic depth. You have to manage your resources, maintain diplomatic relations with other factions, and keep your army well-fed and happy. The battles are also challenging and require strategic thinking to emerge victorious.

The game also offers a multiplayer mode, which adds to its replay value. You can compete with other players online or team up with friends to take on the AI.

However, the game has its flaws. The AI can be predictable at times, and the campaign can become repetitive after a while. The game also requires a high-end PC to run smoothly, which may be a drawback for some players.

Overall, I would recommend Total War™: ROME II - Emperor Edition to anyone who enjoys real-time strategy games and has an interest in ancient Rome. The game offers a great balance of strategic depth and immersive game-play, and the multiplayer mode adds to its replay ability.

This time I picked the Arverni tribe, because don't we all like a good underdog story? After several in-game decades of brutal campaigning, shrewd diplomacy, and economic subversion, my Gallic Federation stretched out from the Iberian peninsula to the isles of Britannia and the forests of Germania. The green banner of the Gauls proudly flew over what was once the capital of the mighty Roman Empire. Mortal eyes, ever afraid where the Gallic blade would strike next, looked upon my works and despaired...!

Then, since I had mostly neglected internal politics, a civil war tore the federation in twain and I had to watch helplessly as half the settlements I had left were sacked and/or conquered by all the armies that used to be mine to command.

I'm not even mad because I absolutely love the drama. Win or lose, this game is pretty epic!

[h1] The definitive historical Total War [/h1]

Total War: ROME II is one of the most divisive games in the entire series, probably on par with Attila in terms of the divide. At launch, ROME II was a complete disaster, and that is putting it lightly. It was a buggy, unstable mess that barely worked and when it did, it ran so unbelievably poorly it made you feel ill. If this was the Original release of ROME II, I would probably be giving a negative review right now.

This is not the case with Emperor Edition (Abbreviated as EE from this point onward).

EE and subsequent patches have fixed most, if not all, of what was wrong with the original release. It runs well, plays well, looks good enough, and improves on many of the gameplay aspects that powered SHOGUN 2, another Total War I hold extremely dear. A large, impressive map, dozens of factions to both encounter and play as, Roman Legionaries, improved diplomacy, naval invasions, Roman Legionaries, tech trees that advance your empire with many being real historical breakthroughs made by said empires, family trees with succession lines, did I mention Roman Legionaries?

The best part about that whole spiel is that I'm only talking about the base "Grand Campaign". That is nothing to say about the 4-5 other maps introduced via DLC.

If you're into Roman history, or history in general like I am, then hoo-boy are you in for a real treat. ROME II: EE is, naturally, focused around the Roman nation, mainly the Republic and Early-Mid Empire periods. ATTILA shows the disheveled corpse that is Late-Empire Rome and its total collapse, but ATTILA is an acquired taste and does not appeal to most. All Campaigns, with exception of "Wrath of Sparta" and technically the base Grand Campaign, focus exclusively on Rome and its history. From the conquest of Italy that hardened the Romans into a truly unique nation, to the Crisis of the Third Century where Rome nearly broke until the "Restitutor Orbis" somehow fixed(?) the Empire. 

Rome II: EE just delivers what you come to expect from a good Total War, it's hard to believe that the original game initially launched in a state so bad that it made launch-day Battlefield 4 look good by comparison.

The one thing I will dock EE for, however, is its price. Original ROME II is nearly 10 years old and EE is nearly 9. It's a travesty that this game is still 60 USD. Thankfully, it goes on sale somewhat often, and often the sale price is very low. As of writing this, its 15 USD for the base game.

TL:DR: A good game today, too expensive for its age, still worth it if you can grab it for under 30$.

After 10 years of putting it off, I finally bought this game.

It's fine. It most certainly is the origin of how New Total War looks and plays. That may be good, that may be bad, depends on how much you love or hate the classic gameplay. Personally I prefer the classics, but wanted things like being able to play Multiplayer campaign with a buddy, and we can't do that in RTW remastered.

I have a very hard time recommending this game to you at full price, as frankly, $60 for *most* of a 10 y/o game is ridiculous in of itself. What makes it worse is CA's DLC practices for this game. I very much so disagree with the cutting of unique factions, and simple graphical features, like blood, from the base game to resell to people as DLC later. If I did my math right, it is actually around $90 to own all of this game, and that is excluding any of the campaign DLCs. I will only recommend this game to you if you can catch it at CONSIDERABLE discount like I did. I paid $30 US for the base game and all of the "Culture Packs" (which are CA's word for "factions from the game you already bought we decided you have to pay extra for, fuck you.") at that price I consider it reasonable. Considering that this game isn't always on sale for 75% off, and that is the only way I feel it worthwhile, I ultimately feel it warrants a "Not Recommended".

TL;DR, Its an okay game, but never worth full price, and CA's DLC practices with it are scummy.

Overall, Emperor Edition provides a solid Total War experience. It's not perfect, but most battles feel epic and units feel responsive to your tactics and commands. The setting is awesome and the stories, grudges, and acts of betrayal and vengeance that evolve during the game drive everything forward. There is enough difference between each region's units and strategies for things to feel different, though I wish these differences were more fully explored. 

The best part is certainly the mid game. For many factions, surviving and putting yourself in an opportune position can be challenging in the early game, especially on higher difficulties. In contrast, the late game largely consists of you steamrolling over the map with very powerful veteran armies and agents. The mid game however, which consists of a handful of powers vying for control, is worth these more tedious bookends to your campaigns. 

I truly wish so many factions were not DLCs, however.

Total War: Rome 2 Emperor Edition is a game that brings to life the rich history of ancient Rome in a thrilling and immersive way. The game is a masterful blend of strategy, tactics, and diplomacy, and it will keep you engaged and entertained for hours on end.

One of the most impressive aspects of Total War: Rome 2 Emperor Edition is the attention to detail that has been paid to the game's visuals. The game's graphics are simply stunning, with lush landscapes, detailed character models, and breathtaking battle scenes that will leave you breathless. From the rolling hills of Italy to the deserts of North Africa, every location is rendered with an eye for realism and authenticity that truly brings ancient Rome to life.

But Total War: Rome 2 Emperor Edition is much more than just a pretty face. The game's strategic depth is truly remarkable, with a wealth of options for players to explore as they build their empire and wage war against their enemies. From managing resources and building armies to negotiating treaties and forging alliances, every aspect of the game requires careful consideration and planning.

Of course, no game about ancient Rome would be complete without epic battles, and Total War: Rome 2 Emperor Edition delivers on this front in spades. Whether you're commanding a legion of infantry, a fleet of warships, or a horde of cavalry, the game's tactical options are diverse and engaging. Every battle feels like a high-stakes affair, with every decision you make potentially determining the fate of your empire.

Overall, Total War: Rome 2 Emperor Edition is an outstanding game that combines historical accuracy with exciting gameplay and stunning visuals. Whether you're a fan of strategy games, historical epics, or just great entertainment in general, this game is not to be missed. So strap on your sandals, grab your gladius, and get ready to conquer the ancient world!

Here are some reasons to play Total War: Rome II:

Who doesn't love a good ol' historical strategy game? It's like being the world's smartest dictator, minus the real-world consequences.

If you've ever had fantasies of leading a Roman army to victory and conquering the world, this is your chance to live out your dreams without the risk of getting stabbed in the back by your own men.

Whether you want to take on the role of the Roman Empire or one of the many other factions available, you'll get to experience the thrill of outsmarting your enemies in epic battles.

You get to command a massive army, and who doesn't love shouting orders at pixelated soldiers and watching them obey without question?

It's a great way to learn about history, except with more blood and guts, and less boring textbooks.

If you've ever wanted to try your hand at political intrigue and building a flourishing empire, Rome II is the game for you.

Nothing beats the feeling of unleashing a horde of elephants on unsuspecting foes, crushing them underfoot like ants.

You'll learn valuable life skills, like resource management, diplomacy, and how to manage a sprawling empire.

There's nothing quite like the satisfaction of watching a well-executed battle plan come together, resulting in a crushing victory against your enemies.

And let's be honest, who doesn't want to feel like Julius Caesar, minus the assassination part?

This game is amazing. Like all total war games catching it on sale is when to buy it. If you can catch it then its well worth the cost even for the dlc. There are extensive mods, an active multiplayer community, and dedicated twitch steams and tournaments if you can get into the right groups. Grand Campaigns are a mix of good and bad. Some people say the ai is easy to cheese and is bad. This is true but its an old ai on an old total war system. Plus mods can easily fix this problem. In conclusion, wait for it to be on sale, get good for multiplayer, install some mods and you have a game you can sink hours into and not even realize it.

:et me start by saying, I'm a lifelong total war fan. I wanted this game to be good. I really wanted that. I've given this game chance after chance, hoping I would finally change my mind about it. I pre-ordered this years ago, and was disappointed by the horribly broken and buggy release. After all this time, I've tried to forgive and forget, and some of my friends told me the game has had serious improvements. I have a much newer rig now, I can run it on high to max settings, everything should be good, right? 

As it turns out, there is a problem persistent in the engine of many of the newer total war games which manages to max out you CPU and GPU usage almost instantly, even in situations that are not graphically intensive. I was able to play the game for just under 20 minutes, when my computer shut down instantly from overheating. I wasn't even playing on the battle map, it wasn't late game, I was simply looking at my building options of my single settlement faction on the campaign map. That was enough to bring my entire system to a screeching halt. 

I grew up an avid total war fan, and I want so badly for this franchise to succeed, but the direction CA has taken is insulting to it's consumers and long time fans. They have repeatedly produced shoddy release after shoddy release, chopped and cut content into pieces locked behind additional DLC pay walls, and spat in the face of those who have been loyal to the franchise since it's inception. It's going to take a miracle for me to trust this studio and this publisher again, and I don't plan on giving them a single cent after the consistent disrespect they have shown to their fan base.

Rome Total War is one of my most favorite games and I've spent countless hours becoming emperor several times. I've waited for this continuation for many years, but it's simply not what I expected. The animations of the projectiles (stones/arrows/spears) looks cartoonish with those white lines/stripes and I don't understand why put such bad effect. The UI and city management looks needlessly complex. You need to essentially decide what to build for each of the four sections of a province and the buildings must not overlap...

After tons of patches the melee units are still making mosh pits!!! Also when enemy flag goes white the unit doesn't immediately route. It has like 2 stages of routing now which is confusing and not needed. 

The fighting in the original game was way smoother and the soldiers looked a lot better (clothing/equipment). Here the Hastati/Triarii look like villagers although this might be historically accurate for some unit types from what I've studied.

On my first campaign (normal difficulty Julii) in just 5 years I easily get to around 15 unit army easily. Seems strange that I generate, so much income at the beginning of the game! Makes me wonder what kind of a scaling factor is there?

I have 450 hours in this game.
And this is an absolute* master piece. 

I put an asterisk there, because you should really look into the DEI (Divide Et Impera) mod. 
It's so easy to install and makes this game one of the best historical games. If not the best historical strategy game I've ever played.

Even now I still haven't optimized my playstyle and I'm still discovering new features and mechanics. The game gives you some goals but they don't really do anything which is why you are absolutely free to do whatever. 

You can have many different playstyles.
You can be a raiding barbarian, looting, razing and sacking settlements. You can go raid territory. Or you can confederate as some factions. You can form the great Hordes of The Steppe when confederating as nomads while you're raiding the others. 
You can be a pirate of Rhodes and liberate the conquered Greek city states and reinstate their old leaders. There are many more ways to play the game that I haven't listed at least one will fit your way of playing. 

If you get the unlock factions submod, you gain access to most factions (These will be less polished as they aren't really legit, but still very playable and fun). If you buy some DLCs on the other hand you gain access to full fledged rosters and factions (each is also upgraded by DEI). (You can even be a satrapy to the Seleucids with this method.)

The tech tree features many reforms and some must be unlocked by meeting certain requirements rather than research. The Romans start with the Marian Maniple system and later on use the Legionary system followed by the late Legionary system. Many other factions have different reforms aswell, all staying true to history ofcourse. 

Each region has different mercenaries from African spear throwers to Indian elephants to light Nomadic horse archers to the great Balearic slingers to Greek pirate ships to f*ng Scottish dogs and chariots. Hell they even have scorpions (ancient LMGs) and ballista (ancient mortars).

There are also new campaigns added. Like the Alexander one, where you defeat the Achaemenid empire and it's satrapies. The Mithradatic wars, a civil war where Pontus is involved in as well. Then the Sparta and Hannibal DLCs have been reworked really well and are polished.

All in all, I would never have even thaught about refunding the game, runs smooth, works and with the much needed mod, amazing! There are also some other mods (like medieval ones i believe.) 
But for some classical strategy this is THE go to game.

In any case i recommend buying the DLCs from legit key dealers or steam sales as I find them a bit too expensive.
quality game. really fun to play and learn.

The good.

• The game is stable and optimized.

• You have some mods to enhance the game.

The bad.

• Agents, too powerful and unbalancing. You can win wars with a fraction of the armies realistically needed if you win before the agent contest. Solution = No Agents mod

• Provincial system. It's a silly transposition of a late imperial political organization. Makes no sense at all when tribes and minor factions are still alive, and harms some factions and others not. Solution = Sara's Single-Region Provinces

• Unprotected settlements. In a time of war and uncertainty is impossible to think that settlements have no walls. Please think about Numantia, sixteen months to surrender the city and in game has no walls, this is simply unbearable. Solution = Sara's Single-Region Provinces

• Too much money. You can expand your economy and simply crush your foes spamming army after army, if they have ports worst still, because the high cost of navies means that you will gain soon the mastery of seas. Also you can have your armies in permanent campaign without any penalty. Solution = Supply Lines & Logistics

• Imperium system. Each level of Imperium (power) have a limit for armies and agents recruitable. This is a silly and cheap way (not very effective) to limit the AI spamming generals while trying to ease the snowball effect late game when the player is too powerful and nothing can stop him. Solution = Bison's Immersive Army Limit / Sara's Single-Region Provinces / Community Patch For Rome II

• Late game boring. When attained certain level of development the AI becomes rapidly powerless, you may add some chili to spice things up. The bigger your empire, the bigger the hate from other factions. Solution = Realm Divide: ROME II Edition

• Time goes too fast. Your generals die of old before achieving any glorious status, your armies need one or two years to sail from Egypt to Crete. Solution = 12 Turns Per Year

• Battles are too fast and AI is silly. There is not much to do in order to help the AI to fight better, but some improvement can be done. Solution = Rome Total War Classic Combat / Ancient Combat

• General Menu and Battle music is strident. Solution = Alexander Music / Aeterna Troy Music Pack

• You miss some refinements from Attila or Warhammer. Solution = Community Patch For Rome II / Dresden Sack, Liberation And Diplomatic Options Mod

• The Roman are tomato red. Yes, that's a concern, but you have a plethora of reskins and even custom units to fill the gap, also graphical improvements to battles, settlements or UI. Unlike the music part I will not recommend anything specific.

Despite all the "bad" I pointed Rome 2 is a recommendable game for everyone who loves antiquity and wargames. With mods you can improve the experience but don't expect perfection. If you feel too lazy to tinker with your (mod) load order you can try an overhaul like Para Bellum or Divide et Impera.

Total War™: ROME II - Emperor Edition is an absolutely fantastic game that I have spent over 500 hours playing and I have truly enjoyed every single one of them. The game offers a vast and complex campaign mode that immerses players in the historical world of ancient Rome, allowing them to control one of the many factions vying for power and dominance.

The level of detail in the game is truly impressive, from the beautifully rendered 3D landscapes to the intricate and historically accurate unit models. The game's AI is also top-notch, providing a challenging and engaging experience that keeps players on their toes.

One of the standout features of this game is the grand-scale battles, which are truly epic in scale and provide an incredibly immersive and satisfying experience. The game's battle engine is incredibly well-done, allowing players to control their units in real-time and make tactical decisions that can turn the tide of battle.

In terms of gameplay, the game offers a wide range of different playstyles, from aggressive expansion to a more defensive and strategic approach. The game's diplomacy system is also well-done, allowing players to form alliances and engage in diplomacy with other factions.

Overall, I highly recommend Total War™: ROME II - Emperor Edition to anyone who is a fan of strategy games or has an interest in ancient history. With my 500 hours of play, I can confidently say that this game is an absolute must-have for any strategy gamer.

This is an excellent Total War game! Since the release of the Emperor Edition, it continues to stand out for me as the best historical Total War to date. The DLC is great, too. The Empire Divided DLC had one of the most memorable Total War campaigns and I love the variety of units across the DLCs. The historical setting, mix of grand strategy and real-time battles that are the hallmark of Total War, and interesting tech tree and character leveling are all well-done in my opinion. The game is on sale often enough to great deal, too. Add the DEI mod and get even more out of the experience. A definite buy for strategy gamers.

This is my most-played game on Steam. The reception upon release was pretty dismal but this has ended up being my favourite Total War game. 

I pretty much play exclusively with the Divide Et Impera mod - which completely transforms the base game into a complex, immersive and (sort of) historically faithful experience. 

Despite the negative reception this game received, you can tell a colossal amount of love and work went into crafting this game. The details on each unit, the historically accurate armour (from real-life museum pieces), the sound design of the weapons and armour clashing and banging, the interactions between soldiers on the battlefield - who scream and shout at each-other and lock into brutal one-on-one combat. The music is sweeping and beautiful.

The graphics are still absolutely beautiful 10 years on and I still stop to admire the scenery frequently. Despite strangely not-to-scale trees and other strange quirks on the battlefield. The commander/leader portraits are the ugliest around - with gaping fish mouth-ed animations. Yuck. They still have legacy versions of these with 3D portraits in the latest TW games - which I find mystifying as they are so rubbish!

One of my favourite things to do is to pause the game mid-battle and look at the combat up close, it is amazing just how much happens and the complexity of the troops. The battle gameplay isn't perfect  - orders can be clunky and troop behaviour can be erratic, even with mods. Sieges battles are pretty dreadful and the maps all look the same after a while. 

In my view Rome 2 is a flawed masterpiece. Perhaps still haunted by some serious problems in development but with time, and on reflection, is one of the best they've made. What is a more peak 'Total War Experience' than building Rome up from nothing to dominate the known world? In a world that feels ancient and alive - campaigns that feel epic and grand. With a little help from mods - this game can do it in a way NO other game can.
Rome NEVER DIES

Compared to Medieval total war 2, it's a way less fun game. City building is very limited and dumbed down in comparison, you constantly feel like you have far less input or control over your settlements, a lot of mechanics consolidated into one or just outright missing and battles are far less strategy and formation orientated as all units seem like they do the same thing regardless of who you are fighting against - you just don't get the level of civilization exclusive tactics or ways of playing you did previously. The biggest kick in the balls is civilizations that you play against in grand campaign are locked behind DLC paywall - which is an abhorrent practice of the gaming industry. Remember when we used to get actual expansions with different campaigns, content and new units and mechanics? Like what the Total War franchise predecessors used to do? Yeah - none of that here, you get a game with portions of it locked behind cash-grabs. 

On top of all of this, the game is STILL plagued with game-breaking bugs. Save files randomly get corrupted or glitched at turn 100 to where your camera no longer works - meaning you have to restart a brand new campaign. Siege artillery on walls does not fire. And this is a decade after the game has been released.

To give it credit, the politics mechanic is an interesting implementation and is a plus, and the graphics are an improvement over Medieval 2, but as far as gameplay and content goes - it's just lacking and a buggy mess. It's a real shame too - I really really really want to like this game, and have been trying to get 'into it' several times now. However every time I give this a shot, I end up going back to Medieval 2 or Shogun 2 after a couple of hours as those predecessors are simply superior in terms of gameplay and content.

I still remember how excited I was for Rome II's release in 2013. Needless to say, we were ALL massively disappointed with the pile of dog feces we got. It was the first Total War that didn't blow me away. Let alone the bugs. The campaign was utterly lifeless, there was no "family tree", and not even NASA computers could get a good frame rate. This game was awful when it first came out, and in turn it seemed to start a trend of Total War games just not meeting the community's expectations.

Here we are 10 years later an I cannot recommend this game enough. I dare say, they "fixed" the game. A version of the family tree was brought back and bugs were squashed over the years. The game at highest graphics settings is still visually very impressive. I run the game at max (extreme) settings and 1440p, on an RTX 3070. Very smooth, no stutters, consistent 60fps. The AI is not batshit stupid anymore either and provides a fun challenge

Do yourself a favor and download the "Divide et Impera" total conversion mod. This mod made the game 100 times better for me. There are boatloads of new units (which are very historical and realistic), the AI is intelligent, they do not get unfair bonuses, and the campaign is just straight up challenging fun. The modders took some of the elements from Attila and put them in Divide et Impera. I'm 65 turns into my Rome campaign and it's extremely challenging. I'm still battling for basic survival on the Italian Peninsula. Diplomacy works really well in the mod too. Neighboring factions will not just get mindlessly aggressive and attack you for no reason if it doesn't benefit them greatly. Establishing trade agreements is more realistic than before too.  

Just buy it!

The campaign AI is so unfair. Like the enemy factions don't have to worry about populace, food, money, army upkeep, etc. However, you do else you'll have an angry populace but at the same time need to build an army large enough to defend against back to back healthy enemy armies that can move thrice in 1 turn even though you've had agents wreaking havoc on their settlements and garrison. It really isn't fun to see hours go up in poof for blatant bullcrap

Edit: I am now addicted to the game after several retries, getting better each time
