Here's a campaign I did. I, Sparta, decided to go assist Athens, my ally, with killing Epirus, no one likes them, but the moment I go and help the "military alliance"  I had with them and Macedon disappeared as they declared war on me. I'm just sitting there with a damaged army up against 2 stronger opponents. My main army is currently smushed in between Macedon and Athens with Epirus re-gaining an army. I noticed that Athens moved it's army to get closer to Sparta, where my small army is at, and took the opportunity to absolutely destroy them. I sent my main army, which still has some minor damage, down to Athens then forced marched my smaller army to get into range of the reinforcement circle, auto-resolved the siege of Athens. I now only have to deal with their armies. The Athenian armies fearing for Athens, ran back to retake their home. Their army started sieging down Spartan controlled Athens. I fought a battle and won, leaving me a Epirus, who still hasn't fully recovered, and Macedon. Macedon had already took some of my land and were ready to take me out. I recruited more soldiers to bolsten my armies, and I rushed over to deal with the small invasion force Macedon had greatly underestimated me as they sent small army hoping that Athens would do the heavy lifting. their army was dealt with quickly, and I re-took my land that they stole from me. I now had my sights on Macedon themselves as they were in a conflict with the barbarians to the north. Using the this advantage I quickly stole Macedon's capital before they could even react. Their attempt to re-take it was laughable and was dealt with quickly. With 2 port cities under my control I set my eyes on creating the most powerful navy the world had ever seen, this and another navy was esential for many victories. 

After dealing with Macedon I laughed as a barbarian tribe gave Epirus a good beating, but they had failed at conquering Epirus which allowed me to sign a peace treaty with them and become friends. Now why would I do that to my enemies when I had such an advantage? 1 easy answer, Rome. They had became great friends with them and continuing this war may lead Rome to join in, and I was no where at the level to even start thinking of dealing with Rome. I had remembered a previous campaign in which Rome declared war on me which lead to the worlds strongest navy and military to rush upon my poorly defend cities. I could barely hold on when I fought the first wave and Invading them would be neigh impossible. With a new found friend, I took to spreading my empire, and I looked northward. I quickly dealt with most of the northern barbarians and quickly took most of Europe. Until, Lusitani had declared war on me. At the time I was still fighting another barbarian faction. Most of my European victories came from pre-war planning and knowing where the enemy was most vulnerable. Now that I'm still in France as Lusitani was in Spain, I had no info of their power nor their vulnerabilities to exploit. I tried to quickly rap up my war to get to dealing with Lusitani, but I had seen something that any general would crap their pants at. A mass mobilization of multiple 20 stack armies and a couple navies heading straight toward Greece. With this started retreating my most powerful armies back to the Greek homeland. My previous navy, who had won me may battles, was stationed near Rome to deal with pirates, and was now being moved back to the port cities of Greece. An army on sea had gotten into my view, but was quickly scared off by my navy, this is saved me trying to re-take Greece as my armies were still a long way away. The newly weakened offense started to have difficulties in mopping up the rest of the barbarians and to get to fighting/defending against a Lusitani European invasion. This gave them the time to fully mobilize their troops to get close to Egypt, one of my major trading partners and military allies, which their threat had never came to fruition as Rome, now an ally of mine, declared war on them blocking all access of Egypt. Rome did loose a city, but such a port city was never  a concerning loss. My armies are now in position to protect the Geek homeland, and to start an offensive. In their rush to take my capital down they completely forgot to defend their lands. From the intel I could gather, Rome and my other allies in the region took down most of their massive armies and navies in the sea, but what I still had to fight was no walk in the park. 

My slowest invasion had commenced. I succeeded in keeping my wars within only a couple of turns and another couple to mop up any issues arised from the war. This had become longer in the previous war as it came to a close I had to retreat most of my fighting force, but now without a massive push as I could've prior my 2 weakest armies (and a strong reserve) had to deal with a still formdiball foe. My armies now at their weakest had the support of some barbarian nations that I had left alive due to this war. With their support I still only able to take a bit of land compared to what I was capable before, this was a failure, a massive one at that. One of their armies had finally came back and my armies were split apart to try and take more land. My third army had finally finished it's retrofit to a more powerful army was not able to get to my army in time. The enemy army had finally engaged me, this was my most experienced weak armies but still filled with nearly no mid/top tier units. Auto-resolve had told me that I would quite horribly lose this army and the settlement I was protecting. I continued to engage in the battle ready to deal any damage to the army. In the battle I noticed that they didn't actually have any cavalry, and once I had engaged in the line battle I started charging into the enemy's back lines alowing me to come out as the victor, but still with a wound that would take a bit to heal. My now hurt army was close enough to re-engage the retreated Lusitani army, and my 3rd army was also in range which proved the end of the first Lusitani counter offensive. At this point they still haven't gotten the bulk of their might back to their homeland but they were near. I continued my campaign and took over another city with the assitance of another navy and my 2nd army. I now was ready to make a massive push into their territory cutting them straight in half untill I noticed their armies had arrived. Now Lusitani had made another, final, counter offensive which backfired and allowed me to take more land. I kept on pushing and took over all of Spain and Portugal. They now only have a city in Africa, the one they took from the Romans, and  I had mobilized my main navy which was currently attacking it. I engaged it in a battle and used my long range artillery to take many of the defenders down but not taking it for myself. They had also noticed that my armies are near by and retreated from their city in which Knossos assisted me in taking the city. That was it they had no more cities, and I could now deal with them and win my drawn out war. 

That is the point in which I got to. I hope to continue this campaign and [b] TAKE OVER THE WORLD [/b]. Allas, I hope you enjoyed this little campaign!

[h1]Most matured Total War as to 2022.
The Best: Amphibious assault.
The Worst: Boring late game and Diplomacy AI[/h1]

This title is the right culmination of many things tried previously in the franchise. Again on one of the most interesting time periods, from the rise of the republic to the early Empire, with units a bit less ridiculous than in the original ROME, but still with some charm here and there. Game still fun even with the more realistic touches.

Is hard to compare it with the original title, because it became a cult classic and its faults are fun. Here we have less shirtless units, not that many meme strategies and the unit roosters feel better put together. Of course you always gonna be on advantage playing as any roman faction, but the flaws on them are well thought and add a good challenge.

Civil wars and rebellions are just part of daily live here, which is very historical, made in a manageable way but hard enough to make you suffer from time to time. Makes you humble to face units 2 tiers above yours after been beating lots of unorganised barbarians for so long.

Naval warfare is really fun all on itself. You have to really polish your boarding and ramming tactics. Unit skills timing are as important as with land units. At times they feel more like land battles on water, until you found yourself losing a unit because hull strength went down. It's so refreshing since you fighting in many dimensions.

Then we have the bonus that you can coordinate land-naval assaults on settlements, which is a magnificent addition. Maybe overpowered at times, because the AI rarely will coordinate them well. Although you need to limit yourself on the amount of exposure you want your expensive naval units to be. This is one feature that I would have liked to see perfected past ATTILA. Sadly it didn't.

The settlements industries and economical upgrade interface is simplified and ends being very effective. Is not as distracting like in EMPIRE, even if this last has more visual appeal, it eventually ends up being too overwhelming. ROME II does a great job on giving you enough information and interaction for those turns you handling too many dozens of settlements.

Some bad aspects in the game design are the unit portraits, they are now stylised and I think are a big misstep. In all previous titles you have portraits that were taken from the unit appearance on the tactical map, and is really helpful to know what they meant for. That's something gone here, low tier unit portraits aren't that much different to endgame ones, and the designs certainly have an effort on conveying some information but I think they failed on that. You have to spend more time reading names and descriptions.

Graphically the game stands up very well. In EMPIRE we had a big jump on quality but the settlements and siege looked horrible, here we have very beautifully made and detailed cities and towns. You don't feel repeating the same siege over and over that much, and that's an amazing job, because apart from making this aspect look good, they did it in a way that enriches gameplay.

Late game with any of the main factions is as usual, very heavy on management and boring on battles, but that's not a particular flaw of this game only but something that happens in most Grand Strategy/4X games. It does not help at all when you playing as Rome, so you certainly have to step aside and grab some barbarian, greek or eastern factions to get a different POV.

EDIT:
As a last addition, to try play the game leveraging heavy on diplomacy can be a waste of time and cause of many headaches. Is not rare factions to never accept peace, even if you left them without any settlement and are just a random general alone with 90% attrition. This happens quite often and may limit the terms on how you engage in war, because most the times you gotta have to fight a faction further than expected.

Overall is an amazing game that has aged well, with the right balance of seriousness and fun, very mature game design and enough stuff to do to keep you hooked. Not a history class but certainly lots of good fun.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Although the game launched in a broken state, it is now one of the best Total War games in the series.  Luckily CA stuck with it and kept updating, patching and releasing good DLC. 

This is my favorite Total War game, for its grand map, combined features and eventual polish. Campaign map plays well, battles are excellent, visually still fantastic and as always the sound design team does an amazing job.

Features added which stand out to its predecessors. Legion/Army mechanics. In addition to stances, armes themsevesl can level up and gain passives and special abilites that influence it both on Map and in combat with its own skill tree. Excellent feature to truely make that extra connection.  
Combined water and land battles. Your ships can land on the shore and join the fight. Artillary can attack cities or armies near the coast. It doesn't seem like a huge thing until you actually do it.
Revamped Poltics and family trees. A much more details (possibly too much so for some peoples preferences) of many actions to boost your family/factions pressence and control of the faction and outside and internal threats of civil war. Fun and interesting options to use diplomacy, espinoge and subterfuge in teh family and politic tree screen. You can marry, divorece, adopt, groom, educate, party, praise, scorn, bribe, assasinate and much more. 
Massive battles and armies. Now you can have reinforcing armies, join the battle in addition too instead of reinforcements. Specically, you have 2 armies? 40 units will be on the battle at once instead of the 20 and trickle in reinformcents one at a time. Making huge forces and a much deeper strategy of army building and support army building. 

The DLC much of it is very worthwhile, base game is still my favorite and I still randomly pull up this game and plow into in over a weekend and expect to put at least a couple hundred more hours into it. 

I suspect I'll never have it uninstalled and will keep coming back to it for likley decades.

Well, I think I am finally one of the veterans with +12000 h. (you would have to subtract some hundreds from when I fell asleep).

The good.

• The game is stable and optimized.

• You have some mods to enhance the game.

The bad.

• Agents, too powerful and unbalancing. You can win wars with a fraction of the armies realistically needed if you win before the agent contest. Solution = No Agents mod

• Provincial system. It's a silly transposition of a late imperial political organization. Makes no sense at all when tribes and minor factions are still alive, and harms some factions and others not. Solution = Sara's Single-Region Provinces

• Unprotected settlements. In a time of war and uncertainty is impossible to think that settlements have no walls. Please think about Numantia, sixteen months to surrender the city and in game has no walls, this is simply unbearable. Solution = Sara's Single-Region Provinces

• Too much money. You can expand your economy and simply crush your foes spamming army after army, if they have ports worst still, because the high cost of navies means that you will gain soon the mastery of seas. Also you can have your armies in permanent campaign without any penalty. Solution = Supply Lines & Logistics

• Imperium system. Each level of Imperium (power) have a limit for armies and agents recruitable. This is a silly and cheap way (not very effective) to limit the AI spamming generals while trying to ease the snowball effect late game when the player is too powerful and nothing can stop him. Solution = Bison's Immersive Army Limit / Sara's Single-Region Provinces / Community Patch For Rome II

• Late game boring. When attained certain level of development the AI becomes rapidly powerless, you may add some chili to spice things up. The bigger your empire, the bigger the hate from other factions. Solution = Realm Divide: ROME II Edition

• Time goes too fast. Your generals die of old before achieving any glorious status, your armies need one or two years to sail from Egypt to Crete. Solution = 12 Turns Per Year

• Battles are too fast and AI is silly. There is not much to do in order to help the AI to fight better, but some improvement can be done. Solution = Rome Total War Classic Combat / Ancient Combat

• General Menu and Battle music is strident. Solution = Alexander Music / Aeterna Troy Music Pack

• You miss some refinements from Attila or Warhammer. Solution = Community Patch For Rome II / Dresden Sack, Liberation And Diplomatic Options Mod

• The Roman are tomato red. Yes, that's a concern, but you have a plethora of reskins and even custom units to fill the gap, also graphical improvements to battles, settlements or UI. Unlike the music part I will not recommend anything specific.

Despite all the "bad" I pointed Rome 2 is a recommendable game for everyone who loves antiquity and wargames. With mods you can improve the experience but don't expect perfection. If you feel too lazy to tinker with your (mod) load order you can try an overhaul like Para Bellum or Divide et Impera.

"That's all for now, thank you" Tolfdir, College of Winterhold

The AI is extremely hard. So hard to break their morale and not only that but when you make your units fight against any AI unit, your unit will always lose. Basically for every manual battles, you have to always skirmish your enemy units using your missile units until they are no more. Sucks that you cannot win any battles that easily. And the cavalry charge (at least on player's perspective) is shit. I charged into the enemy unit's rear and they barely lost any units. So I have to rinse and repeat. But by doing it, my cavalry units are the ones that are slowly being reduced.

I would want to love this game because unlike Medieval 2 where the diplomacy is shit, the diplomacy in this one is pretty good. But the combat just sucks. 

Maybe I am just a noob but I can handle the likes of Shogun 2 and Medieval 2's battles just fine even in hardest difficulty. It's just, in the case of Shogun 2, it has so many bugs like enemy bow ships can fire flaming arrows during the rain and they keep on getting more and more fullstack of army each time. And in Medieval 2, the diplomacy is shit (everyone hates you).

Sigh. How I wish that CA would have that almost perfect game where its battles are fair wherein the AI are not too overpowered, little to no bugs like in Shogun 2, and diplomacy isn't crappy like in Medieval 2.

So far, it seems like Napoleon is the only game that fits the criteria.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

I've always loved the gameplay in Total War. The mix of grand strategy and real-time battles has always appealed to the child in me - pretending to be an ancient general or warlord is great fun - and beating back a faction which betrayed your diplomatic agreements to take advantage of your weak position is satisfying. There are a few bugs in this game which are slightly frustrating but far from game-breaking. The music isn't as iconic as in the original Rome: Total War, in my opinion, but all in all, the musical and visual package is lovely here. 

The biggest problem I have with this game is its developer, Creative Assembly. There are so many DLCs for this game, many or all of which arguably should have been part of the main game itself. Separating the Greek States out as DLC, for example - ridiculous, I think. That's the reason why I only recommend buying this or any of its DLC with a heavy discount - I think you can pay less than $2 each for most of its DLC packs when on sale.

Mods have saved this game. The CA version was a train wreck when it was released. Original review (pre DEI mod) is below:

By far the greatest disappointment ever released by the Creative Assembly. This game was over-hyped in the weeks and months leading up to release, and the final product was months away from being ready for release. Adding insult to injury, the moneymakers at SEGA/CA have decided to release add-on packs for this incomplete game so that you can pay more money for the content that should have been there in the first place.

The shortcomings of this game are too numerous to mention, but the worst of it is the lie. CA hyped a game that they simply failed to deliver. Thanks to their handling of this release, I will never again purchase a prerelease game and I will think twice before purchasing anything at all from the Creative Assembly.

Let me start by saying I am a dedicated fan of the Total War series. My personal favorite being Empire Total War. I purchased this game (Rome II) and spent a whopping 65.00 on this game, only to get about 3 hours into it and the campaign camera has frozen. If you google this issue with the keyboard camera controls not working on Rome II, you will see a large amount of fans displeased by the same issue I have run into. In order to fix the issue I have to download a program and edit the save file (sounds easy right?) and then load my save. I had to spend another 20.00 on WinZip to extract the program to fix an obviously common bug that has clearly not been resolved by this company. If I spent 5.00 on this game I could see that Im overreacting, however I did not spend 5.00, I spent 65.00 on a game that I only played for 3 hours before it was rendered useless. At this very moment I am still trying to get it fixed. Terrible programming!!! Shame on you for releasing this with as many bugs as this game has.

To be honest I have a hard time putting into words why I enjoy this game so much. First off I love everything regarding Ancient Rome especially so in the era in which the transition from Republic to Imperial rule took place. So if you enjoy historical battles during the time of Alexander the Great, Julius Caesar etc, etc then this game is for you.

Most of the mechanics are the same as in the other Total War games except this time there is a limit on building/producing single units instead you have a fix set of armies and you cannot separate units from your army.

The town mechanics also work differently compared to its predecessor and it isn't always clear what the direct benefits are of a building and/or how to manage them. Overall though still highly enjoyable game.

The only issue I really have with the game is the political system they revamped it twice but I still think its terrible.

I recommend just playing Vanilla first, than trying out some of the mods that add even more depth

It's far more historically accurate than the first one, and it has a lot more interesting mechanics, with differing families in factions who will vie for power and do everything they can to get the most influence, a lot of interesting skill trees. The graphics are quite impressive even for today, and there are some mods that can help in that area even more. The battles are still a lot of fun, and seem to be a bit harder when they're more even, the enemy AI even in vanilla seems to field better armies overall, and a better mix of units. 

Overall if you like the first one, you'll like this even more, it's much more in depth and detailed, and feels like it's even more authentic to this period than the original.  They also make the AI better in many ways, for example, in vanilla rome, the enemy AI never reacts quickly enough, if at all sometimes if you start attacking some of their cities while they have armies pushing elsewhere. With some of the mods they make it so that the AI does respond quickly, if not immediately and they move to protect their unprotected cities quickly, so it adds a lot more dynamic realism to it in that manner I do highly recommend using some of the mods after you play vanilla a bit, some make the game a bit more difficult and purposely slower, while expanding It's also hard to expand very quickly, because of public order issues, unless you're playing as Rome.  Some of the mods also do a tremendous job adding a lot of new historical units that look amazing.

Rome II total War is by far the most advanced, well optimized, and most realistic modern Total War to date. Each unit type behaves in a way that is appropriate with Antiquity: The calvary specifically, perfectly embodies the limitations of the time. However, some of the heavy eastern Cataphracts are a chilling prelude of what is to come after the next 500 years of warfare. Ranged units also play an important role. Their missiles are satisfying to track into targets with breathtaking sound design; it's also very immersive how arrows or javelins will stick into armor and shields. However, at its core, Rome II is an infantry focused game. Legionaries, Greek Hoplites, and Macedonian Phalanxs dominate the battlefield with ruthless efficiency, and rightfully so. Faction diversity is another major strength of this game. Having the campaign map stretch across most of the known world, at that time, is a huge plus. There are definitely certain faction blueprints: Roman, Barbarian, Greek, and eastern. Although, there is some overlap within these major groups, each culture has their own distinct feel and play style. Multiplayer battles specifically, have some of the best sieges in the Total War series. Field battles also offer a distinct contrast, as certain more skirmish heavy playstyles become accessible to the player. If I had any complaints about the game it would have to be the subpar blood and gore DLC. This add on will cost you a few dollars and the difference is very minimal. Unique beheading animations are uncommon and the blood itself looks very fake when splattered on models or the ground. Overall, Rome II Total War is an awesome game and 100% still worth the money in 2022. I pray Creative Assembly one day returns to making quality historical titles to this scale and detail.

From a buggy, rocky start to a pretty solid game. This isn't CA's best work, but it's certainly not their worst. Most of the DLC can cheerfully be avoided (especially the beasts of war pack, Beehive onagers are worse than useless since they cost upkeep and do sweet FA on the battlefield) and the base game is easily modded, so if there's something you don't like about it... well, there's probably a mod for that. The political system is pretty crap and I have never managed to make wall mounted artillery actually do what I want them to do... but like I said. Not their worst. Pick this up for £10-15 and you'll have a reasonably good time for a hundred or so hours.

As someone who started on Rome 1 and Medieval 2, Rome 2 is a bittersweet reminder that capitalism despite all of its positives has its flaws. Let your mind pickle at the thought that on release, which was 2013, almost a decade ago, Rome 2, which was hyped for years, was unfinished, broken, unpolished, and still sold to the masses. Alongside locking behind Sparta and Greece a purdy paywall.

Games like Half Life 2 and Rome 1 were completely reworked and built from the ground up after getting about 75% of the way through the game. Now a robot marketing investor who I'm pretty sure are all reptillians sent from hell would think; "Waste of time! They should've continued work and finished their game!" Because that same disconnected emotionless unempathetic robot would only be thinking of the profits they would make on release, and not the actual quality of the game. The reason Rome 1 was so good is because even though they were so close to completion, it still wasn't good enough and those developing it KNEW it wasn't going to be good enough, and so they wiped everything, kept the good parts and started again. And so Rome 1 came out and changed gaming forever, and is still very very fun IMO. I have about 150 hours on Rome, and only about 70 on Rome 2. Why?

Because Rome 2 wasn't rebuilt from scratch or delayed. It was forcibly released to please reptillian investors (Who I believe should either go submit to Jesus or go kill themselves) And knowingly was unfinished and in a terrible state. Hilariously, and unsurprisingly, CA did this a couple years before with Empire, and have done it with plenty of other new releases. To add, most of CA's staff is not the original team who made Rome, and much of the team have left, which I can only assume is because of passionless leadership and incompetent management. F3cking investors. Always want their money.

Rome 2, itself, after years of passionless and mind boggling "work" has actual managed to be a decent enough of an experience. But there is a serious lack of soul in comparison to Rome 1, and many things are just never going to be as good or as streamlined as Rome 1. Some improvements are quite obviously the engine, which is better suited to modern hardware, the graphics, which look real purdy, the animations and collisions are alright, not better then Rome 1 but not worse, the actual combat itself doesn't feel that different from Rome 1 or Med 2. The DLC and whoever decided to make it the way they did should definitely go hang themselves, I have no respect for over exploitation of middle class by uber rich investors, please go kill yourselves. 

Outside of my hate for the marketing team r@ping CA currently the game is enjoyable, plenty of mods (THANK GOD FOR MODS) that save the game, because of developers not being able to see what made Rome 1 so good and only what ever their higher ups demand, (after all the team that made Rome 2 HAD NOTHING TO DO with Rome 1 so its a miracle it is somewhat decent) There are plenty of shortfalls with game design decisions like with limited armies, the god AWFUL political system that is just annoying and boring to use, it feels shallow, the building system is good, so overall, a nice 6.9/10

There's two kinds of those who write the reviews on Rome II - those who played original Rome and those who didn't. For those who didn't played it is a good, epic strategy. For those who played - it is a strange (not to say ugly) bastard of Rome and Warcraft.
Endless bugs, absence of the family tree, taking cities without siege weapons, buttons that magically replenish energy, drunken brawl instead of clever tactics - there's much said about all of this, no need to repeat. All this rage is not about bugs, it's about game mechanics, that became RTS in a bad meaning of the term.
Particular word about music - it is... wait, is there music already? I'm don't remember. I remember Jeff van Duke's soundtrack in Rome till now, but soundtrack in Rome II - it's a pitiful attempt to depict something epic.
Little secret - Rome II Emperor Edition - it is, in fact, final release of the game. First release was alpha, that was released without disclaimer that it is an early access. But whatever, the game is a fail. 6/10, and only for merits of the previous games (excluding Empire, that was also fail). 
Summary - I was foolish enough to preorder this. In future, I'll buy CA products on 80% sale... maybe.
P.S. Wait... CA is developing Alien Isolation? Well, gentlemen, it's the end of the Total War series.
P.P.S. After some time, I decided to give this game another chance. 10 years after release. And, after 10 hours or so, it crashes and still crashed after reload. This game is a misery.

I have 1872 hours on this game. So if I didn't recommend it, I would be a little crazy (I might be anyways.)

The Cons:
Rome 2 is a game which promised much, and didn't fully deliver on many promises. I remember the state it launched in, and that state is the reason I no longer pre-order games. I suspect this game's development had staffing issue; it was clear that the developers couldn't quite get this game off the ground, possibly due to difficulties translating the Warscape engine to an era which relies on big blocks of organized units to win the day. 

Many issues such as formations blobbing into each other, lack of proper collision, and over-reliance on matched animation fighting were present in Shogun 2 as well. But samurai breaking off to fight duels felt *good* somehow, and the units' Japanese dialogue, the screams and shouts and noises of units colliding, the artstyle and music all helped one overlook such problems. 

Rome 2, by comparison, felt shabby. Units spoke English across the board; Romans had their traditional Hollywood British accents, as did the Greeks, and "Barbarian" factions oft sounded like idiots, with such sage quotes as "RRRAAAAAH." The voicelines of the individual units are usually pretty silly, and the noise of units colliding is surprisingly lowkey. 

The music is a sore spot for many, though over time I've grown to appreciate Richard Beddow's soundtracks. There was a sort of "bait and switch" that happened amidst the game's marketing and launch - in promo trailers, Creative Assembly used Jeff van Dyck. In-game, we got Richard Beddow. Comparing the two composers, I think Creative Assembly wanted music that better fades into the background, whereas Jeff van Dyck's music has always been heavy hitting and head banging good stuff. Though I don't mind Beddow's OST, I do think the game's audio mixing somehow manages to throw the music further back than it should be. I often play with master volume low, music cranked up, and cranked up in the Windows volume mixer to get a better overall audio balance. 

The UI tried to do some era-matching by making unit cards that look like they come right off the side of ancient vases. Neat idea, but I had trouble telling units apart mid battle, and ultimately just found the whole thing unappealing. There are some that love this design still, and that's cool - it's just a personal taste thing. 

There are some nuisances on the campaign map. AI armies frequently get stuck in places. The diplomacy is barebones and the Campaign AI (CAI) is either completely passive or murder hobo'ing across the Universe. Desert attrition is sort of silly - you're supposed to stick to roads in desert regions to avoid taking massive attrition damage, but the algorithm that determines how you move when you click a destination will frequently route you offroad. The result is doing tiny clicks to move forward a centimetre, saving the game, then moving again, and reloading if you go offroad. 

There was clearly some struggling getting units to even run correctly in a formation. Even today, units sort of rubber band back and forth as they run so they don't phase into each other. It just doesn't look good, and it breaks immersion. 

The matched battle animations are straight up bad; I'm not sure if I've ever seen worse. It is clearly two mocapped dudes pretending to fight each other, *slowly.* They do not even aim at each other for certain swings. Ultimately, fights look great a distance, and really funky when you get up close and pay attention. 

Naval battles are still buggy today. They are not as bad as they used to be. When the game released, I remember a naval battle in which my ship and an enemy ship conjoined with each other, floated up and into the air, then slid off the map together. Occasionally you will still see some weird stuff like this (in fact just a week ago I recorded a ship slowly doing circles on a beach) but mostly it is just hard to get ships to do what you want them to do consistently, making important naval fights very frustrating at times. 

The DLC scheme is...meh. Locking Sparta off behind pre-orders was a mistake and the fandom let CA know it. Modders implemented factions for the game, then CA released DLC which made inferior versions of these factions with less units, which blocked these mods from working unless you paid CA again. DLC in Rome II locks content instead of adding content, which is unfortunately the spirit of many games these days - later CA games do a much better job with DLC, but this one doesn't. 
Blood DLC is also an instant thumbs down from me due to sheer dumbness. I don't want to hear ratings arguments (some suggest Blood was made DLC to dodge an M rating), because FreeLC would've worked were that the case. 


The Better:
Rome 2 is better than it used to be. The devs took some more time to polish the game and re-released it with Emperor's Edition, thus clearing out their negative review history and updating the game to what it should've been at launch. Mostly. 

The AI IS better behaved, animations DO work better, battles make sense and function better overall. This is what makes the game worth a buy on a steep sale. 

With DLC, there are lots of factions to choose from, some different campaign scenarios you can play which may or may not be worth it, really depends on how much you are interested in those specific time periods. 

There is a ton of unit variation in this game: pikes, hoplite phalanxes, sword units, spear units, various ranged units, siege equipment, basically everything you would expect is here. Pikes feel proper powerful from the front and Romans just grind things down into dust over time. 

Missile fire looks great, with arrows spinning and bouncing off shields. Artillery looks and sounds great as the shots land. 

Units will react to missile fire by raising their shields in unison. It looks a little odd when they do this as there isn't much of a transition animation and they all just do it at once, but seeing those shields all raised up to block the oncoming missiles looks awesome. Pike formations also look pretty damned cool. 

Ultimately the gameplay with Emperor Edition feels good. It's still got that clicky, satisfying, *something* that Total War has always had, and it is possible to sink many hours into a campaign, catching the well known "one-more-turn-itis" which keeps you from going to bed on time. 


Modding:
This is separate from the rest of the review because the game deserves credit for having decent mod support, but doesn't necessarily deserve credit from modders' efforts to make the game even better. 

There is a longstanding, large, experienced modding community for Rome 2, with massive overhauls and tweaks being offered in the Steam Workshop and on the TWC forums. You can tweak almost anything. 

Personally, I use Divide et Impera overhaul mod which adds many new units and mechanics to the campaign, along with many graphical tweaks, such as more dust, smaller arrow trails. I also use Rome I music, and some smaller campaign tweaks, such as one which removes desert attrition. 

Thus, my game is like a totally different game, using Rome 2's solid bones to create a much better experience overall. And that is the Rome 2 I have sunk nearly two thousand hours into. I encourage any player who buys this to try some campaign and see how you like it, then head to the workshop and change what you dislike.

TL;DR: Decent but issues prevent this from becoming a long time favorite. 

Pro: 
- For me best overall TW game since MTW2 Kingdoms.
- Stable. No crashes. 0 crashes after epic fights.
- Lots of mods

Con: 
- Core combat issues: You can make formations move in sync as you like but you are unable to place units most of the time properly without the shadow unit formation jumping around so the annoyance starts at deployment stage.  Also if you did manage to get units to seemingly place correctly they may still end up facing away from enemy from time to time or just plain standing there sideways with their flank towards the enemy. Just what?  Can i ignore this and just have your units yolo around on the field? No because
- Units get stuck on battlefield or ignore orders resulting it situations where units just aren't there were they are supposed to be. So you either meticulously spend time doing formations and pause constantly or you ignore the individual units and end up doing worse than you expected because of this and it bothers you. You simply get worse results than autoresolve sometimes and when that happens it's every single time because you just don't get your units to be where they are supposed to be. Small things yeah but if you do it enough times...  
- TW games at best have flowing game play with just a few keys and mouse. Flowing game play = many battles = lots of fun. Getting these two to work together properly here just doesn't work. Why am i able to play MTW2 or RTW so easily yet this one just devolves into cursing sooner or later when i make complex moves? Unit placement in MTW2 isn't easy either sometimes, especially up in rugged terrain but that one still works. Here the end results are surreal most of the time. Showing your back to enemy or just whatever... 
- All the above in the end sums up so that especially big fights are a major chore and annoyance. In MTW2 you do a big fight and it's over in somewhat relative speed and you move on. Here you wrestle against the weird issues and try to move on.  None of the added UX features that have been added here help you get that streamlined experience you had before when you didn't have so many options. Small annoyances pile up. And for that in the end this game narrowly falls under the 'not recommended' flag. I did complete a grand campaign as rome, conquered the world but i will definitely not want to do that anymore. The mods i tried did not help the core issues with how fights flow from user interface point of view and thus i see no other option than to set this to a 'No don't buy this' 

Note here that i don't trash anything else here really. This game IS a worthy successor to RTW but i think they have changed some things so that i don't want to accept it as a long term game to play.  I am even today completely happy with MTW2 simple grouping controls and it allows me to play out just the simple or complex tactics i want. Here i no longer even want to try anything too complex as it will be either lots of cursing or just fail. Which brings us to
- Waypoints - How did they mess this up? Incredibly unreliable. I never do more than 1, max 2 waypoints for a cav unit for example. Always fails somehow. Units stopping. Ending up somewhere else. Some singular enemy soldier stopping the whole thing in it's tracks etc.

I played Rome Total War, Medieval II Total War, and several of the total conversion mods for each game for years. The originals do not run on Windows 10 due to the obsolete DRM software those games require.  

This game was a huge disappointment and is a big step back from those games in gameplay. the graphics are updated and the Empire-like tech tree and settlement management adds depth, but the combat system is terrible, and at its heart, the battles are what a total war game is about. 

in the original game, units occupied space and when two or more melee units collided, the units pressed against each other and didn't pass through. Melee spear units in front of archers, with cavalry on the wings was the classic formation used by Alexander the Great through the Roman Empire. In this game, I can charge cavalry right through an infantry formation and attack the skirmishers behind, and skirmishers can wipe out heavy infantry because their weapons are much more accurate and dangerous than in the original game. 

These seem like engine problems due to the game using the same engine as Empire, where gunpowder units were supreme. Also, because of the games increased complexity, modding is more difficult, and so there is less additional content for the game--unless you count being sold each scenario and faction microtransactionally. total War was the best game franchise in the word from 2004 to 2009, but has steadily gone down in gameplay quality while going up in production value, and its a damn shame.

The launch of this game was terrible back in 2013(?) but now the vanilla game is above average. It still suffers some AI issues (such as aggression, path finding, etc), but you can enjoy your experience with this game. The best experience with this game is with the modding community. In particular Divide et Imperium (DEI). DEI drastically changes the game play from vanilla and makes the AI function 100x better and includes more diversity of nations, units, scripted events, and replay value. DEI is also still supported by the modders as the most recent big update was a couple of months ago. There are other great mods as well such as radious, and there is an in-progress medieval mod that is good. If you are a fan of history/strategy games, I recommend getting this game and checking out the mods
It is a very interactive game, and if you like games similar to Civ 5, Civ 6, or Hearts of Iron 4 then you might like this game too.

If u a history lover, this is a great strategy game

Definitely worth checking out if you're a fan of historical battles or movies in this time period. The game mostly focuses around the Roman Empire but you can play as most of the major factions during that era as well such as the Carthaginians, the Persians, Egypt, Germanic Tribes, Seleucids, and the Greek states (although you'll have to buy the Greek States DLC for any other faction besides Athens, noticeably Sparta). It's great fun playing the Campaign and watching as history is recreated by your hands or just the factions vying for supremacy which leads to varying Campaigns as sometimes even the major factions get snuffed out from the underdogs.

The game also has good mod support for when you get tired of vanilla or just want to tweak the visuals. Some of the more notable ones being Divide et Imperia, which completely changes the game as you know it while also adding in a lot of new content, and New World, which adds more mythological factions such as the Amazonians, Atlanteans, Troy, and many more.

Overall I'd rate it a 8/10. Only reason it's not a 10 is because sometimes the movement for the units can get buggy which is frustrating and takes away from the immersion, especially in naval battles. But other than that I found myself really enjoying this game.

Total War Rome 2 is, in my opinion, not only the best Total War Game, but one of the best 4x Grand Strategy games I have ever played. 

Following the immensely popular Shogun 2, Rome 2 made many changes to the Total War formula, including a generals based recruiting system (no standing armies without a general and the general recruits new units instead of cities), the most advanced economic system yet, and the most expansive family management mechanics to date (as of 2013). All these and more paired well with the tried and true Total War formula to bring the most satisfying and immersive game of the series.

There’s a big debate between fans of whether or not these changes were good, but I think they are. I don’t mind tying armies to generals. The complexity if the economic systems may take more than one playthrough to master, but it enables to player to make strategic decisions about planning their economy. A grand design that balances Industry, agriculture, culture, trade, religion, and sanitation is fun and satisfying in a way that no other Total War has been able to really nail. 

The combat is detailed and fun. There is less of an emphasis on playing the battles, which I enjoy. The auto-resolve is fair and reliable. When I am playing Total War Warhammer 2 I sometimes feel like I need to play every battle and that can be both good and bad, but Rome 2 offers a more relaxed playthrough for those not interested in fighting tons of battles.  
 
The unit variety is great, unmatched in Total War games with the exception of the Warhammer games because they obviously have many different races and technology levels to work with. Each ethnicity and culture has its own unique feel. Naked celtic warriors, Dog handlers, War Elephants, Anti-Cavalry Camel spearmen, Parthian horse archers, Sobek cultists, Phalanx, and many many more fun and distinct units to use in battle! 

The game has 6 distinct DLC expansions. They add new campaigns with unique mechanics, maps, and other features that I find to be lacking in the DLCs of the Warhammers, which for the most part just add new playable factions. DEI Mod is incredibly popular with those who want to kick the game up a notch. 

I would absolutely recommend Total War Rome 2 as a great starting place for the Total War Series as well as a great game for fans of the series to pick up.

WOW! Why did I buy this game? Oh yeah, because I waited years before buying and paying full price for it and because I waited for a super-low sale where I wouldn't if I did not like the game anyway. Wow, I still don't like it and am pissed I actually paid money for this. I shoulda listened to aaaaalllllllllllll those reviewers reviews instead of trusting TOTAL WAR game lineage.

This game is a sad continuation of the Total War series. From what I saw in videos of the "creators", or people in charge of the game, they had changed a lot of the mechanics and other things that worked well in the previous games. On top of that they added unnecessary mechanics like the Senate/Political management system. This is TOTAL WAR, not a sim/resource management system game. This is supposed to be a game where you can progress due to your battlefield prowess not whether or not you can "bribe" Senators.

The combat AI is wonky at best. Some times I have 3 or 4 full units fighting one unit and that one unit is not only fighting and holding their ground, but depleting my 3 or 4 units, even if a unit is attacking them from behind. It seems the enemy AI's one unit can not only hold my many of my units but can kill them until the rest of their buddies show up. What's even more funny is that broken and routed units will now run back and attack my units in the rear, this after they've had their asses handed to them and have routed half way across the map. You try to use and fight according to "battlefield" tactics but these tactics just don't work in Total War anymore.

What killed me was when I took a HUGE army to a town or city, destroyed its garrison and army and then said defeated army runs away and on the next turn it has replenished its troops and added several more units, much more than what I have. I just decimated them and they suddenly have MORE troops than I do. I call BS.

Should I talk about Squalor? It's the stupidest concept. I try to upgrade my cities but I spend more time spending money on getting rid of the Squalor areas that pop up in your cities.

It's impossible to keep your population discontent down and your bread up. Especially when most of the upgrades for your areas don't include positives for these MOST IMPORTANT features like population content and bread.

The bullshit Senate management and civil war possibilities. This was the things that totally made me stop playing the game and write this review and will soon delete the game from my hard-drive because it is taking up space in my game hard-drive. This is actually the first time I will delete a Total War game in the middle of playing it and I've owned and played all of the major ones since the first Shogun decades ago. Without even waiting for the Senate to tell me to attack Carthage, I swept down the Italian peninsula and started attacking and taking Carthage territories. This and the reason that historically what was done. I'm ahead of the strategic "game". Nonetheless, I took over Italy, Sicily, the two big island west of Italy and took Carthage(city) and Libya and was heading west to finish off Carthage(enemy) when suddenly the Senate decided to go to civil and half my areas and armies changed hands over to the "opposing" Senate. I had a HUGE army heading west across Africa and boom that army belonged to the AI. What's funny is that I went back to play the Iceni and was expecting NOT have the same "Roman" political system, but it has the SAME POLITICAL SYSTEM. How does the Iceni have the same political system as the Romans? I was like oh boy, they just copied and pasted the same EVERYTHING onto every other culture. Lazy game developing.

I've played games where the developers make the game "harder" and say that benefits the game to be more playable. No. You're just amping the hardness just to make it harder cause it's a shit game to begin with. I've played many games and the shit games follow this format. Make the game "harder" because it lacks content and gameplay. 

I'll leave you with something I saw on an old 80s TV show. There was a boy character that met a game arcade owner and the game arcade owner told him the secret of his monetary success. He told the boy that he sets the game to very hard and that "there is no level 10" therefore kids keep dropping quarters trying to "reach level 10", which doesn't exist. Just like these games that people ruin or create that don't have a "level 10" but they call it "hard gameplay" because there literally is no content after a certain point.

I'm an old-schooler from the 80s and I'm not buying anymore Total War games but I WILL BUY games from new indie developers that won't follow bullshit formats or concepts or "the message" narrative. My money will speak and I will keep in my pocket until I find something worthy of my money. Plenty of games out there to play and I can always replay all my old games which were well made to begin with, unlike this one.

Deleting this piece-a-shit game.

Although I am a Total War fan I just can't get into this game. I don't feel challenged by the decisions of enemy factions but rather artificially held back. The garrison for every minor faction , even if it owns one settlement, its either a full stack or two of units just sitting there and so going through them is a mind numbing grind. Then getting the province in order takes forever. There is almost no motivation not to auto resolve because you know the exact outcome and even if you lose your army it can be replaced in like three turns; 
and since the AI can do that too , defeating enemy armies is unrewarding. As a result, the game doesn't feel organic at all.

Over the course of six years, I have (at time of writing this) played Total War: Rome 2 for a total of 926 hours. I don't think there's another game I've spent so long in except for maybe Skyrim. Rome 2 is to me what Rome 1 is to a lot of people. I have some incredibly fond memories playing this game, and it's one of a precious few that I always come back to. It's just new enough that it doesn't feel painfully dated, and just old enough that it doesn't feel frustratingly dumbed down. To me, this game represents the golden age (or pax romana) of Total War games. It has that *chef's kiss* special something that I have found almost nowhere else. If you enjoy ancient Rome (or ancient civilizations in general), this game is for you. If you enjoy real time battle simulators, this game is for you. If you enjoy turn-based strategy, this game is probably for you (more gritty and in-depth than Civilization in many ways, but not as complex as Imperator: Rome -- do with that what you will). The DLCs are also a lot of fun and I've spent a lot of time with them (some are admittedly better than others). Sorry I'm not good at writing reviews for games I like this much, but this is an S class one for me for sure. I can't promise you'll like it as much as I do, but I hope you do. Any Total War game is a lot of fun, including this one; however, this one is far less polished than its predecessor "Rome 1". The battlefield AI is clunky at times -- missile troops refusing to fire, awkward troop movements -- and the enemy AI is pretty weak and easy to trick. The political system is also greatly lacking, and much of it has little useful function. The game lacks motivation beyond "take over everything", and can quickly become stale. But overall, the setting is great; and if you can overlook the fact the your troops have arranged themselves into a ginormous blob with one awkward thin tail in formation, then the game looks beautiful.

If you are looking for a fun strategy game of this type, I would highly suggest the sequel to this game "Attila". The setting and general feel is similar, and the game is far more polished. It is perhaps my favorite game in the Total War franchise.

The best Total War game full stop. It has it flaws, but don't we all.

Pros:

Graphics are just superb.
Needs some overhaul mods like DeI (Divide et impera) or Radious, then the game has a better feel.
The unit expansions make it better, because Italian factions (besides Rome), arabian factions, have an otherwise limited unit roster.


Cons:

I feel like it would be cool,  if in late game, one faction wasn't owning like an entire country (i.e one faction ruling over Germania). This way, you'd have to fight a number of factions when coming into a new area. 

I.E if I were to invade Africa late game, I'd want to fight [i] all [/i] the African factions and not just one ruling over the entire place.

This is the best Total War game in over a decade, hands down.

The best part of Total War games has always been the historically accurate uniforms, units, banners, etc.  It's a real detriment that Creative Assembly decided to do some bullshit warhammer thing for 8 years.  With a fictional setting there is no chance to have historically accurate anything.  I honestly do not understand why CA would even agree to make a game that could never be its best just from the get-go.  

THE GOOD:
This game has all the units, factions, historical accuracy, bla bla, everything we want from Total War.  

This game has multiple missions with varying units, strategies, etc.  

Giant game board!  Not as big as Empire of course.  Empire was truly the best Total War game ever and I wish CA would attempt to meet/beat that honor.  


THE BAD: 
This game suffers from the same detriment as all Total War games: Not enough maps.  There are like 3 cities and 5 non-city maps.  Much of the joy of generalling is using terrain to our advantage and, like all Total War games, this one utterly fails.  Most of the maps are just a flat rectangle.  

Artificially limiting units to "must be attached to a general" makes this functionally much more of an RPG than a strategy game.  The way to win this game is to level up your general character, not be a good general.  Artificially limiuting the number of generals is just plain stupid.  I'm sorry, I tried for literally years to think of some sort of justification for this, and I just couldn't come up with anything.  That was a bad decision through and through.  

Bottom line if you enjoy Total War games, this is another one to add to the collection.  Not the best (obviously Empire, or maybe Shogun 2).  Not the worst (literally all of the Warhammer bs).  

If you enjoy strategy games I gotta recommend Empire: Total War.  After you're done with Empire and Shogun 2, move on to this game and Attila.  If you're still desperate for more Total War after that I recommend (roughly in order): Napoleon, Medieval II, Shogun, Alexander.  

I end this review with a plea to Creative Assembly.
Look guys I fell in love with strategy games.  I fell in love with history.  Will you please stop the rpg bs and move back to strategy?  Will you please stop the warhammer bs and move back to historical accuracy?  Thanks guys.

Absolutely obsessed with the series but this rendition never ran well on my prior Dell XPS so I finally called it quits. Not the game's fault though. Anyway, if you like Rome: Total War, you will likely buy this game. It's an okay upgrade but there are many things I don't like. For instance, the complexity of managing empire building is still a little shallow compared to similar games. The graphics are good and all but it feels almost cartoonish compared to Rome I. The buildings, unit options, etc. aren't really much different. I get it... it's the same empire so the same units and buildings about apply between games but somehow I expected the complexity to increase and there to be more upgrade tiers available between buildings and such. It's really just the same game but with prettier graphics... which maybe is what people wanted. 

Also, be warned, I upgraded to the new MacBook Pro with an Apple chip since Steam claimed Rome II would work on the machine... it does not. It opens to the ROME II screen then disappears. I can hear the noises but nothing I do will allow me to see the game. Some other games work extremely well (Civ, for instance) but not this one.

I play this game since it was released in 2013 and have dumped nearly 1000 hours into it.

Conclusion in advance:
Recommendation for all fans of the ancient era, explicitly Rome, who are willing to pardon some gameplay issues like instable performance and stupid AI. For players, having their focus on pure gameplay, there are better historical Total War titles available (e.g. Shogun 2, Three Kingdoms).

Positive:
The game is atmospheric and can provide a lot of pleasure. It does NOT want to be historically accurate, but that is okay in my opinion. The unit diversity – especially with the many DLC’s – is impressive. Also, that each faction feels different to play. The great campaign map is huge and beautiful in my eyes. The units look very detailed and authentic. It is great fun to build up your empire step by step and to conquer the whole ancient world. Since the 2017 update CA implemented the family tree, which was sorely missed by fans of the first part.

Negative:
During my years with Rome 2 Total War, I had many different performance problems. Sometimes it crashes between the rounds, sometimes at the beginning of real time battles. I got used to save before each battle. So that is annoying, but not a big deal.

The biggest problem, all Total war games (even the new ones) have, is the completely stupid AI. If you are looking for a challenging experience, play anything else. After a few battles, you know how the AI reacts in each situation and you will win nearly each battle by using simple strategies. Difficulty level only changes the number of opponent full stack armies on the campaign map. Most of the balance issues are fixed in the meantime, but there are still some slightly overpowered units (a unit of Oathsworn can kill almost 3 Roman legionary cohorts) and some, which are completely useless and consequently unplayable. Sea battles are a bit notchy.


In view of the hundreds of joyful hours, I had with Rome 2 TW, I definitely have to recommend it even 9 years after its release. But keep in mind, that there are problems, which won’t be fixed very likely in the future. For me the positive side predominates.

I dunno dude. There's just something about this game I don't like. The act of playing is is clunky and boring. I can't play for more than a couple minutes without getting really bored.

I think I have a fair amount of hours to say that overall, this is a really good game, and so far, my favorite total war game.  However in saying that, I do not believe it is the best total war game.  While I love it very much, I fully acknowledge that previous total war games twice it's age still were doing better in many aspects of play, and enjoyment.  Though I don't think that means this game is a total let down, as I genuinely love it with a passion, and my complaints while sometimes major aren't deal breakers.

My first main complaint by far is difficulty.  This game is often times far too easy, as some factions will not stop steamrolling once the ball is rolling.  Rome itself is apologetically overpowered, and while they are the literal name of the game.  The problem resides that it makes Rome almost unfun to play if you know what you're doing, as even a 12 man garrison of a random town in Africa, will often have over a thousand legionaries more than capable of holding of 4000 of a mid tier enemy army.  Which leads further into difficulty, as the AI will almost never field high tier armies, often opting on some occasions for mid tier armies, and almost always resorting to a low tier spear units that at best roadblock you from progress for 5 minutes.  To some this might be a bonus, but I think it hurts replayability very much.  You can only have so much fun killing spear units that do a whopping 13 damage to your 105 defense, 60 damage, javelin volley throwing maniacs known as almost all mid tier sword units, let alone the high tier ones you'd surely field after decimating spear armies for so long.  

What should be mentioned is this is not always true, as for some factions, the difficulty is actually quite good because the early game is challenging, which makes the mid to late game steamroll feel rewarding.  Almost all celtic factions suffer from public order very badly, and as such, make it very fun as you have to manage your budget, and armies accordingly to prevent revolts.  Empire divided for me personally has the best Rome experience, as Aurelian's rome is horrifically hard early game, and the subsequent unholy steamroll that follows if you don't give up, is immensely enjoyable.  

A few other complaints I have are missile units feel very poor compare to older games in regards to sound design and animation.  This is admittedly small, but noticeable.  I encourage you to watch medieval 2 gameplay of archers vs rome 2.  You'll notice a very noticeable decrease in quality in sound design, animation, and even graphically.  A game almost a decade older outperforming a new game in the same franchise is borderline unacceptable.  I am willing to forgive it as ultimately archers in Rome 2 I believe preform far better than in medieval 2 in terms of combat effectiveness.  Usually being honestly op in some scenarios if you really focused on bonuses just for them in mind, but I digress.

On to some positives that make me come back to this game a lot!

Rome 2 has many, many factions.  A total of 117 (DLC included), however many share a lot of the same roster, and culture, but often field a few unique units and buffs to them exclusively.  Regardless of the of the "samey" kind of feeling many factions can offer you due to similarities, it still is a lot, and even just half of them being good is more than enough to satiate someone's lust for replays.  However, I want to immediately highlight 6 in particular I think deserve recognition.  3 I've personally played, and 3 I think look extremely unique and fun, DLC included.  

(Factions I've personally played)
1. Kush (Desert kingdoms dlc) CA went far too hard for the desert kingdom dlc in general, all of the factions are glorious, but Kush stood out to me in particular.  Fielding one of the most unique rosters I've seen, and that is almost always capable of being improved.  All while being in an amazing start position.  Makes this faction an absolute treat to play. 

2. Aurelian's Rome (Empire divided) As mentioned, this is Rome, but challenging.  I imagine many won't like it on that merit, but to those who do.  Aurelian's rome was one of the most difficult, and rewarding campaigns I ever played in a total war game. 

3. The Roman republic (Rise of the republic).  Once again, Rome but hard.  Very hard, however it usually steamrolls very quickly once you take care of the pesky, but numerous neighbors immediately hostile to you.  The roster being of the very early Roman republic, which most would hesitate to even call a professional army, feels incredibly different from base game Rome, and empire divides.  

(Factions I plan to play, and believe will be very fun)
1. Carthage.  Carthage is the only playable punic faction, and one of only two factions to have 3 dynasties to choose from to get a variety of different faction bonuses.  This coupled with it's free upkeep merc army capabilities with enough dedication, makes it seem like a constantly changing and unique army builder.  

2.  Nabataea. (Desert kingdoms dlc) A desert faction that embraces Hellenistic culture, and solid cavalry.  A dream come true for me, as Hellenistic and desert factions are by far my favorites.  The roster including pikemen, desert hoplites, and axe and sword units seems like truly a treat to behold for battles.  That in the income trade bonus is actually amazing if you really take advantage of the Mediterranean.  

3.  Macedon.  Probably the ultimate greek faction, giving you all of what you could want, with what I believe is the best pikemen in the game.  Coupled with hopelites, and fairly good cav.  The hammer and anvil was never better than with this faction!

Overall, I think I've ranted on enough about this game, perhaps to an unhealthy degree.  

My ultimate take is, I love this game, and I almost wish I could go even more in depth.  I however do fully admit, it might not be for everyone, and that's okay.  I give it a strong recommend, and think the desert kingdoms dlc, empire divided, and rise of the republic are very worth while dlc purchases, if you do so happen to enjoy.  Thank you for reading, if you did.

This review is strictly for SINGLE PLAYER aspects of the game, i have not experienced the multiplayer just yet. So this was the first of the total war games that I have experienced, and if i'm being completely honest it's way better than i thought it would be and i'm hooked. The game has a rewarding single player campaign where there are hours of gameplay not only dedicated to RTS gameplay but also a reasonably well implemented politics and economy/settlement management system. Granted, sometimes the settlement management and political stuff can be a bit tedious, but it makes the game a pretty cool simulation of the political, economic, and military climate at the time. I'm a sucker for realism, and of course the different factions, settlements, and tactics you can use in your gameplay of the campaign feel very real and open ended. Once you start learning how to manage troops in battle better, you can hike up the difficulty and things start actually feeling challenging. Granted it's not a perfect game, and I have heard bad things about the price to quality ration of the DLC(although I have not bought any yet myself), but if you can catch it on sale I'd say it's a good buy and a fun single player experience.

Edit: Ok so after additional time I definitely have more criticisms of the game and am overall less optimistic lol. Not a huge fan of the AI just straight up ignoring a lot of the obstacles players have to deal with(like public order and money since they can mysteriously turn up with a full stack mercenary army a turn or two after losing their last settlement :P). In addition to this problem the AI also gets very repetitive in battles just running straight into the opposing line and paying no attention to unit types and whatnot. Also from what I've gathered CA has made some controversial decisions in "streamlining" the game to make it more accessible and less complex. Now I don't know how true this is but I have definitely noticed in some of the older fan made guides that a few old mechanics or terms are used. All in all not bad but has a few annoyingly glaring issues that I wish CA would address (and I know the ai issues are complex so i certainly dont claim to know anything about how to fix that). I haven't played with many mods yet but I've heard high praise for the Divide et Impera mod so I may go check that out next since it appears to add some needed variation back to the game and change the way the campaign events and ai work.

- Also, look into the DLC before you buy it. The faction dlcs can be either really good or really bad and the new campaign scenario dlcs are only worth if you want something other than grand campaign.

I played the previous instalment of Total War: Rome in the mid-2000s when I was a teenager. Already it was quite a complex and overwhelming game, but it had many enjoyable aspects too.

When it comes to Rome II that's yet another game that's fallen into the trap of over-complication. It is nearly impossible to win while keeping finances balanced, which rips the joy out of everything. You need to be keeping an eye onto all sorts of stuff and can't really delegate administration of your settlements to anybody. However you do have annoying advisors who will provide all sorts of futile information while bringing very little actual value or contribution to the task of military conquest. Can't understand why the advisor doesn't provide any information of value regarding deployment of military units, formations and how to counter opposition armies.

Another issue is how time consuming the game is. There are no convenient options to save games so once you're under way you are pretty much stuck with having to complete many turns.

The combat mode falls short in that it does not really give an indication of whether you're winning or not. Much of the combat looks very even until suddenly one of the competing forces gains an upper hand, out of the blue.

This is not Age of Empires: it is meant to be a game that is inaccessible to all but except a tiny minority of seasoned gamers. Not worth spending a lot on, thankfully I got mine while on sale and didn't lose much on the purchase.

Overall this game is good, but your gameplay experience will depend on the faction and difficulty your choose. Some factions might be too easy to be interesting to play and others might have mediocre geopolitical issues, but there are some factions that are gold in this sense. Strongly recommend the use of mods to tweak some mechanics.

I'd strongly recommend the Getae faction. You start really small with pretty weak units, but it only makes your expansion and development the more fun. The faction also start pretty neutral with the many neighbours, but within a few years, you will be forced to pick sides in war (or sometimes you don't even have a choice given how things play out), whether it becomes east vs. west, north vs. south, you against all, or all neighbours united against the aggressive and expanding Macedonian faction. It is a lot of fun.

You won't always win with Getae, and that's the best part. Seeing your or another thriving empire expand and collapse through strategic and regretful decisions is the pinnacle of strategy.

I have the brain to handle the complexity of the game (99th percentile on the LSAT and have read and understood 1,000 page insurance policies and even had to prepare an Appellate Brief back when I practiced law). Okay, this is a tough one. I started playing Total War a little late (2015) with Medieval 2. Medieval 2 set very high standards for Creative Assembly to follow. Both simple and complex where it needed to be. Rome 2 is the exact opposite. The politics system is pointless and unrewarding while forcing you to dump money into it otherwise it creates a snowballing effect of rebellions, secessions, and more secessions. Do not get me started on the AI and pathfinding. More often than not, the units will do the exact OPPOSITE of what you tell them to do. The game is much more micro intensive than it should be due to the broken unit AI which is more than content to stand there allow themselves to be shredded by skirmishers that are not even 10 feet away. This is just a fraction of the issues you will run into on any given campaign. As for naval combat, I cannot even put into words the amount of frustration you will experience just trying to get your units to WORK not even half way through the battle. I will close my rant there because I have not even begun to scratch the surface of what is wrong with this game.

However, I cannot give this title a bad review because despite all of its many, many flaws, it provides an experience that most games fail to deliver. There are a few improvements from Medieval 2 that this game brought (a lot based on preference) such as the large amount of unit and faction/cultural diversity throughout the game. Most playthroughs will prove to be a different experience. Instead of 20 major factions, you have roughly 70 city states/small kingdoms with a few minor empires to start things off, which is quite a lot of variables for different outcomes in each campaign.

Aside from the broken aspects of the game, the main problem however is how hard it is to finish a campaign. Once you conquer half the world, the only things really stopping you from further conquests is time, patience, and public order. It's a very repetitive process and turns end up taking longer and longer as your empire grows. Anyways, after 700 hours of gameplay, I thought it was about time to write my review.

It's a good game, I'd catch it on sale. There are a lot of things I don't like about it like the AI mostly, you have to constantly baby sit the units or they will try to run through enemy formations. Then there is the Player bias, that computer AI has.. there is The ally system that sucks, coordinated not really.. because you coordinate an attack but the AI just ignores it. Why it is even there when the AI just basically ignores the order I don't know. Why does your allies stand next to a town being attacked and not help I don't know. Most of my issues are just with bad AI.. and it's not that the enemy AI is bad, the enemy AI is great but make them your ally and it acts instantly worse.. So it's like fighting the game because it's using every way it can to just make it harder on the player. Including having enemies gang up on the player. I can say it's not bad if your not trying to get the total war achievement etc..  The AI is kind of trash, and can be frustrating..  It will spam the player with agent actions, but if you make anyone an ally the AI gets instantly more dumb.. I think the main issue I have with many of the total war series is that Computer players never have the same rules the player does it seem.. they don't seem to have to afford the units, or go by any of the same rules a player does. 

It's a frustrating mess but, it's still an alright game.
