Rome 2 received fair criticism upon its release, however as it was my first entry in the Total War series, and I did not purchase the game until perhaps a few months after its initial release, I did not start with sky high hopes and expectations. At the time I found Rome 2 highly enjoyable due to its fun battles, interesting factions, and the only real complaint I had was the cheating AI, something veteran Total War players, and myself, can tell you is simply part in parcel with the series. 

Over the years, Rome 2 got more DLC, more expasions, more content, and has now matured like a fine Cyprian Wine. Its bugs have been addressed, its bare bones politics system completely overhauled to the point of being utterly indistinguishable from its original version, and its even received a few additional DLCs long after other Total War games have been released and discarded by CA *cough* Attila *cough*. I can safely say that by now it is well worth the cost of it and most its DLC, especially when you factor in the still quite vibrant modding community.

While a good portion of my hours are from vanilla Rome 2, the lion's share comes from countless modded campaigns, first with Radious, which makes the game more fast paced and adds loads of new units, and then as my tastes matured, with the Divide Et Impera Mod, which makes gameplay more tactical while also adding loads of units based on historical accounts, instead of what just looks cool. All in all, its an excellent game which has, unfortunately, exceeded its predecessor's successor, in quality and content, if only perhaps due to its long tenure of DLCs, bug fixes, reworks, and startlingly effective modding community.

I came to RTW2 as a TW veteran of MTW1, RTW1 and MTW2 (skipped Empire and Shogun2). At first the game-play was so different that it was almost daunting and I longed back to the earlier simpler titles I got so used to already. But I forced myself to give RTW2 a chance because there were some very promising features. And boy was it worth it.
My favorite features that I appreciated immediately:
* Minor faction system. I always hated the generic "rebels" in earlier TW titles. There was never "no-one's" land during history, but this is what the "grey area" felt like: land you can take without consequences. This is gone now, the entire map is filled with life and you have to consider the diplomatic effects of attacking any minor factions. This is so cool.
* Army limit based on empire size. If you ever had to deal with the mindless army spamming of the AI (with 2-3 units each) and the resulting battle fatigue, then you'll appreciate this immensely. It also results in more strategic play, as you now have to consider where you will commit your limited number of armies. You can't fight on all fronts!
* Huge variety of factions, troops and mercenaries (bonus: you can levy troops from you vassals).
* Much improved AI, especially on the diplomacy front. You can actually make peace with a loosing AI and even force them into Vassal status.
* Naval battles (although I suck at them).
* Much larger map, with many more settlements.
* I also appreciate the nice looking graphics.

Features that I frowned upon initially but have grown on me since:
* Province system, with minor settlements not having walls.
* Food system.
* Growth system.

Overall I think this is by far the best TW game I played so far. Note that I got into this long after the initial release, so I didn't experience the bumpy start.

All around a great total war game that had a rough start. Lucky for all of us, CA didn't give up on it... after having initially given up on it. Would love to see it done again but as Medieval III and perhaps and even more dynamic population and political system.

That said, after 5000+ hours and a lot of trying out different things, I think the the game is overall very dynamic and cinematic. If you take time to learn how upgrading your generals, politicans, and agents works, along with the political and economic systems, you can spend multiple turns planning out the logistics of an invasion so that your armies aren't just brute forcing their way through enemy stacks holding their settlements. Makes you feel like a real commander that has options and it makes leveling up your characters and agents very worth it.

Although you can pretty much brute force your way through the map especially as Rome as the AI tends to make dumb moves sometimes even on Legendary. That said, there are plenty of mods that can fit a variety of needs to make the AI a bit better and to fit any other tastes people might have. From the hardcore Total war and history nerds to the ppl who just want an enhanced vanilla experience, the mods for this game are great and abundant. They are a must if you want to get the most out of this game.

I have found that the slow grind and increased time span mods like Divide Et Impera (DEI) are just not for me, but I have finally found a collection of mods that work well with each other to make the vanilla experience much better aesthetically and in terms of combat. The list is below for anyone interested. Note that it does not include the particle effects mods nor does it include any of the graphical enhancement mods that are popular on the steamworkshop for this game. I run it at 1440p max settings so the game looks great to me and I just haven't gotten around to trying the particle effects mods.

MY RECOMMENDED MODS:
- NordoPic: 3D Unit Cards (uses 3D full color unit cards instead of the Greco-Roman 2D art style)
- Rivers of Blood: Gore Edition (DLC required - pretty self explanatory)
- Rivers of Blood: Realistic Edition (also self explanatory?)
- AAA: Generals - Romans (dynamic generals that age and change clothing - other factions available too)
- Reskin Roma.Pack (part of a comp that reskins ever unit to look more historically accurate)
- Reskin Unidades (part of reskin comp)
- Uniform Colours Remastered replaces jarring bright colors from vanilla and reskin w/ more modest colors/tones)
- Any Unit as general (for unit testing in custom battles)
- More and Better Armies - without AI bonus (AI builds more and varied armies w/ better units when able)
- Closer deployment zones (I only use for testing but compatible w/ campaign)
- Realistic cold steel 1.4 (new mod and best mod I've found for vanilla to make unit stats, unit AI, and combat more historically accurate)

Wanted to try out total war but I didn't know where to start so I googled best total war game and a lot of people said this was it, for the life of me no idea why. Sure it's got diplomacy, army management, dynamic relationships between factions in your nation, and character progression, but none of it is really good. You don't actually have to pay attention to any of it and I don't because it's boring and most of your problems can be solved by pressing a button. After a few playthroughs I still have not had a:

-civil war or secession attempt
-war that was hard enough that I was at serious risk of permanently losing territory
-character that I actually cared about or mattered for my faction
-ally that was worth the effort I put in to securing them
-ally that I didn't immediately invade/want to invade after I was done with them bc I realized they were worthless
-client or satrapy that I didn't start the game with bc they're worthless except in maybe a few very specific situations
-food or public order issue that led to a revolt

So the gameplay loop is just invade > secure territory by building the right structures (which is easy and repetitive) > grow army so you're ready for next enemy (also easy) > invade next enemy

And that's it. That's a tutorial for the whole game.

There is some good, the battles are fun to watch and if you're in to roleplaying the expansion of a nation state in antiquity then you can have some fun watching your empire just keep growing. There's just nothing to hold you back or make conquering your 357th nation interesting. Your expansion will be very one sided in your favor after a few hours of gameplay. If you want something like a civil war, revolt, network of alliances, etc. you can do it but there's really no point outside of rp. So my history fan side is like "okay, this is mildly interesting," but my gamer side says "this is the same thing you did last time, why are you still doing this?"

Reviewing in 2022 - Almost a decade later...

I bought this when it was released in 2013. It was awful then and it is still awful now. I have yet to buy another Total War game after playing this one. 

The UI is horrible. In the previous games it was clean and easy to read. Now it is a mess with rough "cards" to display buildings. The soldier "cards" aren't descriptive either and don't provide enough of a difference between units.

Other changes, like requiring generals to move units, limits the player freedom that used to be enjoyed in previous Total War titles. 

Stick with Shogun 2. It came out earlier, yet looks better and the gameplay is much more entertaining.

Unlike most normal people, I played the heck out of the first Rome: Total War (no seriously, I spent a few years playing the large campaign over and over again with the various factions). Then I fell off the face of the earth from gaming since life kicked in. I am only now getting back into it again. So of course one of the games I buy is part two of this game I was literally obsessed with. After 59hrs (so far) on record and I only got the game 2 weeks ago, I can say that yes, it definitely lives up to the first one. It is far more complex and it took me playing through an entire massive campaign where I wanted to win by taking over the whole map instead of through *cough* cheating aka diplomacy *cough* to learn all of its intricacies. I can say that this lives up to the Total War name. Off the bat, I'm telling you let the lady give you all of the tips in the campaign mode even if they are annoying at first. Even if you're not going to use the info she gives you right away, trust me it comes in handy at the very end of the game when you realized how everything ties together. Now go off and build legions Roman to a man!
